The line seems to move pretty quickly so this is an idea spot if the other restaurants at the Ferry Building have long lines.

I wouldn't say that this is the best pastrami sandwich in SF as other reviewers seem to claim...but definitely worth a try. I'm partial to M&L Market or Deli Board for their pastrami sandwiches.
author: Lester W.

description:
Let me start off by saying OH. MY. GOODNESS.

Honestly, a 5star rating just doesn't justify how my tummy feels about this place...it is just that good!

Located in SF's Ferry Building, I believe on the left wing, you will find Golden Gate Meat Co. located next to Acme Bread. There is the Hot Food section where I go to buy their, OH. MY. GOODNESS. Chicken and Turkey Pot Pies.

Chicken Pot Pie- filled with lots of shredded chicken, seasoned with herbs (I believe oregano and lots of it...), mixed with onions in a delicious velvety cream sauce that will knock your socks off! Topped off with the most buttery and flaky crust. I'm going to need a minute to recollect my thoughts...

...okay, I'm back.

Turkey Pot Pie (Thanksgiving dinner in your mouth)- filled with lots of shredded turkey, mushrooms, potatoes and carrots in a velvety cream sauce similar to the Chicken Pot Pie minus the oregano. Also topped off with the same buttery and flaky crust *drools*. Not only does it taste like Thanksgiving dinner it also smells like it.

They also offer a wide variety of other delicious meats and sides such as...
-Beef Pot Pie (will try soon)
-All Beef Hotdog
-Meatloaf
-Sausage on a Stick (mild or spicy) served with brown mustard (one of my favorites)
-Pastrami and Italian Beef sandwiches 
-French Bread Pizza topped w/Cheese, Pancetta and Olives
-Macaroni and Cheese (YUM)
-Grilled Vegetables
etc. etc. etc.

What is also great, is the actual Golden Gate Meat Co. Market Place located right next door, that offers a seating area where you can devour all of this deliciousness and shop for quality cuts of  meats to take home and cook yourself.

Beware. You may get hooked. I sure did!
author: Cat L.

description:
1.  Meatloaf sandwich with mushroom gravy.  Caution: this is at least a five-napkin operation, and you'll still manage to have gravy somewhere on your face or shirt front.  (I've found gravy under my ear.)

2.  Beef pot pie.  Beefy in a very good (is there any other?) way.

3.  Chicken pot pie.  Luscious, with an exquisite crust.

I haven't managed to get beyond these three, unfortunately.  This has been my set rotation for the last few years.  

Terrific sustenance at very reasonable prices.  Check out the cash discount.
author: Mutant O.

description:
The best kind of food coma - the one you dread because you know it's coming. This review is about GGMC's delicious delicious pork shoulder BBQ wrap. 

If you're coming in from the main entrance, make a left and it's a few shops down from Cowgirl Creamery. I swear sometimes I get lost in this building trying to find a particular place that I found on Yelp.

Can you believe that a full rotisserie chicken is the same price as the wrap? I was contemplating getting the whole chicken because... y'know, it's a whole chicken!! Ended up getting this instead because it seemed to be the less... a'hem messy option.

No regrets! The wrap was full of pork and I KNEW instantly after the first bite that I was going to be in a food coma in two hours because I wasn't going to be able to stop myself from devouring my wrap. Yep, that's the best kind of food coma.
author: Jason T.

description:
So there I was in Market Street on a cold rainy Saturday looking for lunch.  That place in the basement of Westfield was like a cross between a sardine can and a sauna. There were lines of poor bedraggled looking sods all over the place - even to get into the bathrooms. Not for me.  I decided to make my own pastrami sandwich and to give Golden Gate Meat Company a try.

The ferry building was a zoo as well.  Who are all these people ?  California is supposed to be broke.  Besides it's raining out.

First stop was Acme where the service was great despite the crowd.  If all you want is a loaf of something Acme beats Boudin.  Then to Golden Gate where the service was also great but the "so called" pastrami was $18/ pound so at that price it would want to be good.

I say "so called" quite deliberately because the meat they gave me wasn't pastrami at all but rather an el cheapo smoked beef that had not really been smoked at all.  It had been rubbed with whatever the chemical is that is used to make extra smoky immitation bacon.  I know the taste well because I can't stand that stuff either.

Hands down this would be the worst pastrami I have ever eaten.  Next time I'll try Wise Sons.
author: mark k.

description: Came here for lunch and ordered their rotisserie chicken and veggie sides. Overall it was okay. Chicken doesn't have much flavor and probably something I wouldn't come back and order. I still like Kinder's chicken. When I come back I might order their pulled pork sandwhich instead.
author: Claudine V.

description: Got the breakfast sandwich for 600 pennies. Thick cut bacon and egg on a bagel. The bagel didn't tear up my mouth and the bacon was delectable.
author: John B.

description:
I ordered the hot pastrami sandwich and a side of mac & cheese. 

The hot pastrami sandwich was luke warm, messy and the pastramis were dry. There was a smear of mustard on the bread. The mac & cheese was also cold and there was no cheese on the pasta. It was macaronis with pieces of bread crumbs on it. 

My friend got a chicken sandwich that tasted better though.

My sandwich and side came to $12 dollars. I can spend $12 at the endless options in FiDi for a better lunch.
author: Terry C.

description: If you are looking for high quality meats and at reasonable price, look no more, this is the place. Great customer service too!! I bought a whole Christmas Pig from them. Thomas the butcher was friendly and was very helpful through the whole process since this was my first whole pig. I didn't want a frozen one like many of the other suppliers were offering, and it was great that theirs are always fresh. I will be using them in the future for my high quality meat needs.
author: bfree L.

description:
I'm not sure if "I'm a fan" because I was starving for breakfast or if I'm really a fan.

I went to the Ferry Plaza Farmer's Market looking for something to eat. Needless to say, I wasn't craving tofu or organic tamales. All I wanted was a nice breakfast sandwich.

And I found it, for a great price.

I mean, the thing was HUGE!

It had egg (perfectly cooked), bacon (oh so good!), and cheese, all in a really big bready english muffin.

In fact there was a bit too much bread, but the egg and bacon were delicious. I'm not the world's biggest fan of bacon, and quite honestly I was looking for a sausage sandwich, but man I didn't miss it.

They have all sorts of delicious looking meat here at a pretty decent price. It had me craving lamb and turkey burgers and anything meat related.

Oh great, now I want a buffalo burger...
author: Vanessa F.

description:
Golden Gate is fairly inconvenient for me, I won't drive to the Ferry Building so I have to take a cooler.  For me, at least, the location is the one minus.  On the positive side, this is the second year I have ordered and bought my Christmas birds from Golden Gate, and been incredibly happy with the quality.  For 2010, I called every butcher shop in town looking for fresh pheasant, every one except Golden Gate told me there was only frozen pheasant in San Francisco.  Golden Gate said they could get fresh pheasant and it was less expensive than all the other shops.  I didn't really believe them after what every other shop told me, but they were sealed by the farm.  I looked it up and the farm said they only ship fresh, never frozen pheasant.  Great tasting too.

This year, I wanted quail, but the frozen ones in the Asian markets don't ever taste as good as the ones in better restaurants.  I haven't tried the store in Chinatown that appears to have them fresh, but they are even more inconveniently located.  So I went back to Golden Gate, ordered my quail.  Expensive (really expensive) but never frozen and deboned.  Usually I debone my own, but this saved me some time.  Stuffed them with cornbread andouille stuffing and roasted them.  Best quail I've ever made.

They also carry Mary's chicken, which I buy close to home but can say is the best chicken I have ever had, and I also picked up my andouille there, which was fresh and good, far better than buying packaged.

If I am in the Ferry Building for lunch, I usually get their pulled pork sandwich, which needs a lot of hot sauce but is otherwise one of the best deals there.
author: Spike S.

description: Sucks. Bbq pork sandwich is just pork meat in bread. Super dry and bread is stale. All their other food looks dry and gross.
author: Ron A.

description:
Best butcher shop I've found in SF.  Want something cut differently?  No problem.  Seasoned?  Just ask.  Want it brined?  Sure.  As long as they have it in back you can probably get it.  I'm tempted to ask for 1/2 a cow, in 1/6 increments, from 3 different animals, seasoned but i'm afraid they'd actually do it.


It's hard to even find half the things they sell and they don't charge you out the nose for it.  They're my benchmark for meats; whenever I have to buy somewhere else I cringe and say "crap, i could've gotten X at Golden Gate..."
author: Matt P.

description: Got the bacon breakfast sandwich while visiting. Friendly service and the sand which was pretty good.
author: Erik D.

description: Pasta in a pot pie? Also, almost no meat to be found, just cheap filler and a bad taste.
author: Louis N.

description:
Dueling Golden Gates.

Golden Gate Bridge is painted with iconic International Orange.

Golden Gate Meat paints their pulled chicken sandwich with honey mustard dressing.

Bridge takes forever to paint. Sandwich takes no time to make. Just the aforementioned ingredients on a roll.

Delicious simplicity for a somewhat expensive eight bucks. One day it will also cost eight bucks to drive over the bridge.

Great sandwich. Even better bridge.
author: Jason B.

description:
The only reason they get 3 stars is because the food is good.  Thumbs up on the pot pie.

They charge $1 extra for credit card.

The workers are INCREDIBLY rude.  I guess when you have 4 customers in line at lunch time that means you can be a jerk to one of them, cuz who cares if you get their business or not, right?

I will never go back here because of how incredibly rude BOTH of the workers here were.
author: Light Bulb J.

description: I got the chicken pot pie. I really enjoyed the texture of the crust and savory flavors of the pie. I gave it 4 out of 5 stars because it was on the edge of being a little bland.
author: Eva B.

description: Stopped by for lunch today. The 1/2 chicken with one side, is a really good deal for the area. Before I left, I pointed out that the ribs looked burnt (they were jet black). I was informed that they weren't burnt - with that snarky attitude others have mentioned.  I told her that was funny, because black meat  is burnt meat everywhere else. She just gave me the stink eye, and walked away.
author: Ebony S.

description:
Here's what you are going to do:

1. Walk to the Ferry building from Twin Peaks.
2. Get their USDA New York strip with the complimentary rub.
3. Walk back to Twin Peaks,
4. Grill the steak until it is medium rare.
4a. Optional - Grill vegetables along side steak.
5. Open up a beer and enjoy a heavenly experience.
author: Chris K.

description:
Went for lunch to the ferrry building and this was the only place that didn't have a line (that should have told me something!)
My husband ordered the rotisserie chicken with mac and cheese and I ordered the pull chicken sandwich. 
The chicken was cold and very dry. The mac and cheese was also cold and cold mac and cheese doesn't really taste good. 
My pull chicken sandwich tasted old so after 2 bites had to throw it away. I couldn't even give it away as I don't want anybody getting sick from it.
author: Cristina D.

description:
this is for the butcher section only:

I come here once and a while to pick up sausages. The service is always great and the meat selection is fantastic. Keep in mind that the meat is of the highest quality and thus is a bit more expensive that you are probably used to paying.
author: Dean M.

description:
Me: "do you like the chicken pot pie?" 
cashier guy: "No" 
Me: "Oh..." 
CG: "i don't like it... i Loooooooove the chicken pot pie!!"
Me: "ha ... ha... " 

And so i ordered it... and damn! it was good!  :D 

Next time I'm at the ferry building I know where to go. the crust is so buttery flakey and yummy and the chicken inside is shredded so you know it's fresh chicken (not frozen chunks) and the veggies and sauce/broth/gravy inside is uber tasty. :)
author: Judy N.

description:
Just in case you're wondering, this is not a male strip club. If your mind is out to lunch and not on it, you may be disappointed not to have a Chippendales-meets-Beach Blanket Babylon experience here. The name actually refers to the meat you eat...let me rephrase that...the meat you cook and put between two buns...let me try that again...oh forget it.

So I seem to be conquering the Ferry Building one pricey eatery at a time. This afternoon, I met my career counselor who took the boat from Marin to meet me. So fine dining was not a top priority ...something fast was sufficient since we were using terms like "Open Issues" and "Action Items" between chomps. In haste, I decided to go for this upscale butcher shop-cum-deli-cum-BBQ joint.

I ordered the Pulled Chicken Sandwich and a Diet Coke, which came to $13. On the high side for a Lee's Deli-kinda guy like myself, but there is no doubt that the sandwich was humungous. Between a large, fresh French roll was a massive mound of pulled chicken slathered rather heavily in a honey-mustard sauce. Picking up the sandwich without spillage is not an option. You need to maneuver a plastic fork around the edge of the roll to keep up with the goopy contents.

It was good, though a bit too sweet for me, and I think I need the lettuce and tomato slices to offset the protein overload. But I should come back and try the more traditional BBQ sandwiches when I feel particularly carnivorous, which is basically at every meal. We sat at one of the bar tables between the shop and Hog Island Oyster Company. So we did get the lingering stares from foreign-tongued tourists passing by throughout our lunch. I gave them a good glare as the internationally recognized sign for "What the hell are you lookin' at?"

FOOD - 4 stars...a hefty, hearty pile of meat...don't wear white
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...typical Ferry Building eatery...but with lots and lots of meat
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...fast, furious and step aside, will ya?
TOTAL - 4 stars...gimme meat, gimme meat, gimme meat
author: Ed U.

description: Had their breakfast sandwich with bacon (other option was ham) and it was delicious! The egg was still a little runny..yummmm! They need to get coffee.
author: Summer F.

description:
I see their truck all over the City, so have you.  But have your TRIED their meat?  Around since 77 (which was a very great year) so they must be doing it right.  Everything they wholesale is worthwhile, so I'm happy for their retail presence.  And the extremely helpful staff!  Great family.  Quality all around.

Power walking at the Embarcadero yesterday, I stopped by the farmers market, nabbed some fruit and headed inside to get some blue bottle coffee.  
GG Meat Co had a sausage on a stick that was pretty much calling my name. 
Glad it did because that was f'en delicious.  Jogging pants, tank top, sweating from a great walk, chompin on a sausage holding a bag of fruit in one hand and managing my coffee in the other. Now THAT's what I call balance.

GG meats.  Yum...
author: Athena S.

description:
The first time I came here I got the meatloaf sandwich, because I love those. It comes with mushroom gravy and there's a hard boiled egg inside. I forget if there was cheese, but if there was it was cheddar and melting inside of the loaf. This is a big fat meaty sandwich when all you want it a big fat meaty sandwich. I've had a lot of meatloaf sandwiches in my time and this is a great one.

Pastrami sandwich. So simple. So good. House-made dijon is not spicy but ever so slightly sweet, so it complements the pastrami instead of overpowering it. The fatty bits of the thinly sliced pastrami lusciously round out the sandwich. It's not like you're going to pull them off to be healthy. This is a simple sandwich of a fresh, crispy crusted roll, delicious pastrami in juices, and mustard.

That's all you need. None of the fancy stuff. This is the sandwich you want to eat all the time but don't often let yourself. Just enjoy it.

Some of the pastrami that was sitting on top of the tray gets a bit dry, so try getting someone to order it before you so you get the meat sitting in the juice. I'm serious, I may loiter around waiting for someone to get it before I do next time.

These are gigantic $8 sandwiches. You won't be hungry afterwards. And if you are they have cheaper meat options like sausage on a stick for dessert!  Service is fast so meat-to-mouth time is short.

Mmmm.... meeeeaat....
author: Amy N.

description:
This one star is for service. 
I've never been so blatantly disrespected in my life. 
I called in early right when they opened to ask then about the different cuts of venison and specifically asked them for a tender cut that could be sliced for korean BBQ style, I even said at least hand/palm length, she assure me the venison tenderloin is what I'm looking for so I ask her to set aside 1 pound. I get there and they bring out my package and its little medallion pieces that obviously can not be sliced... i tell them that this is not what i wanted and the manager was an asshole and muttered to his coworkers how difficult i was and how i didn't know how much this piece of meat was that was set aside.. I'm sorry, I had called in before hand and was far from difficult, making sure I got the right cut..
Manager, you are an ass. I will never come here again, thanks for nothing.
author: Nicoline B.

description:
While I did not try any of Golden Gate's meats, I was very impressed with their selection at their retail store in the Ferry Building.  They had some meats you would not find at a lot of places including different cuts of venison, wild boar and buffalo.

The wild boar tenderloin looked pretty good and it was also reasonably priced.  Their cuts of beef looked good too though they were priced maybe a little higher than what I've seen at gourmet meat shops in L.A.  The steaks did have some good marbling though.

If I lived near here and was doing a special dinner, I would definitely give Golden Gate Meat Company a try.
author: Anthony N.

description:
The meat counter selection looked fancy, but  for a quick FiDi lunch I went to their meal counter in the hallway.  Most of the options looked heavily marinated/stewed, which is suspicious for a place that prides itself meat quality... you'd think a freshly cooked chunk of flesh would taste good by itself.  The food was ok, but definitely below the high Ferry Building bar.  I suppose it's better just to buy the meat yourself and cook it at home.

Sausage on a Stick: This is probably how people ate before bread was invented!  The sausage was crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside.  I especially liked the spiciness.  The mustard smear was a good addition, but messy.

Pulled Chicken Sandwich: I'm a fan of mustard, but this was too much.  The pulled chicken was swimming in honey dijon!  The chicken itself could have stood to be a little warmer too.  The bread was good, but they obviously don't make it there since it's a meat company.
author: Adam B.

description:
I'm not going to lie. I wasn't expecting much from this over-the-counter quickie lunch stop, but boy was I pleasantly surprised!

The honey mustard chicken sandwich was super delicious. Simple yet flavorful, it burst on my tastebuds like fireworks. The bread was soft and fluffy, the honey mustard wasn't overpowering and the chicken was juicy and plentiful.

The only downside? This sucker is messy! Bring a bib, a fork and be prepared to look like you have no manners while eating it.
author: Nikki B.

description:
I went to this place with one thing in mind, the Hot Pastrami Sandwich.  Wow.  Definitely the best hot pastrami sandwich I've had.  Super simple.  It took the lady 30 seconds to put it together.  They start with a good soft roll.  Put on a small amount of mustard they make right there.  Then add a healthy amount of pastrami.  Incredibly flavorful and rich.

It did kill me a little inside that a super basic sandwich cost $9 but after I had it I fully understood.  I'll be back.
author: Brian G.

description:
Every time we go there to eat, the level of friendliness towards customers declines a bit more. Always something bad happens. I ordered my plate, and before my plate was completed, the girl behind the counter began helping the customer behind me, even though there was no reason to. 
Then this other time, when I was ordering, the same person behind the counter was glaring at me and making it seem like it was a huge favor for her to be doing her job. 
Today there was nobody behind the counter and I had to call out to get helped. Took a few tries before anyone came out of the kitchen. 

What's more, is how pathetic it is they have a paper sign that reads "condiments for customers only. 15 cents a packet for non-customers".
It just screams "we are penny pinchers!" can there be anything more tasteless than charging 15 cents for tiny packets of salt? I mean, who does that? It looks bad.

Food is well-intentioned but the way it's displayed is unappealing. I'm seriously taking my business elsewhere at this point. The Hispanic looking girl who fills orders isn't exactly all that kind or nice either.
author: Jade R.

description: It's a good walk from 2nd and Market but well worth it for the BBQ Beef Sandwich. DEEEELICIOUS!!
author: Wallace A.

description: I love the variety of this place, I especially love the freshly-ground veggie/fruit puree-drinks in the a.m. My exGF turned me on to this place (she had a lot of time on her hands when they weren't on someone else) and I love getting the bacon/cheese bagel sandwich things ($6) as early as 7am. Great place.
author: Kevin F.

description:
I was looking for Veal bones for stock and demi glace. Not beef bones. VEAL bones. I sent them an email. Do they have Veal bones?

Why, yes they do.

At the very fair price of under $4.00 a lb, I picked up a whole bag. Also, while there I got 1.75 lbs of top sirloin for Korean BBQ beef. Kinda pricy, but it's 100% organic, and sirloin is never cheap anyway.

The guy behind the counter was very friendly and helpful and offered to cut me a new piece if I preferred. 

Will return!
author: Jordan C.

description:
For almost three years I have had the pleasure of shopping at this butcher.
They are the best.
I drive from Napa to the ferry in Vallejo. Then an hour each way just to stock up.
The selections are amazing, 
I love to cook, and having a REAL BUTCHER SHOP is a dream come true.
Keith always takes great care of me, and the rest of the  staff goes out of their way to help navigate me through carnivore heaven. 
Stop in and experience the best selection and service in San Francisco..
I promise you will not be sorry.
Leave my Beef cheeks alone!
author: Curtis H.

description:
In the mood for a pound of flesh?  Crave some hot, salty goodness?
Meet meat.  Golden Gate Meat.

$7 for a huge pastrami sandwich is a deal, considering most of the other stores in the Ferry Bldg are overpriced.  

It wasn't as good as the best I've had back in NY, but it's damn close.
author: dan s.

description:
Review is for the actual meat deli (gasp).

Bf and I picked up some steaks and oysters from Hog's across the store (hollaaaa).

We intended to buy the succulent filet mignons but they did not look very fresh behind the glass counter. What's up with that? The NY steaks looked much better and so we got 2 of those instead. We also bought foie gras, which the staff admittedly didn't know how to cook. They said some guy bought some, came back and demanded his money back. Apparently he tried to eat it raw HAHAHAH.

Service was amazing. They were so sweet! I'm such a sucker for great customer service. You can sell me a fake Chanel bag but as long as you're sweet and nice about it, I'll love you forever.

JUST KIDDING.

But I AM a sucker for awesome service and this place definitely met that standard. Quality products too, except the filet mignons...but I'm sure you can ask for a fresh piece. No problemo. They gave us some steak seasoning too!

Definitely not a place I'd get dinner at every day (it's expensive) but for special occasions, HELLYES! They have some exotic hard-to-find meats and body parts. Perfect for an adventurous night of cooking at home!

And yes, our dinner was UH-MAZE-ING.

I'll be back to purchase more foie gras unless my conscience tells me otherwise.
author: T L.

description: I love Golden Gate Meat Company. It's close to work so I never have to worry about not having time to go to the butcher shop before dinner. GGMC has a great selection of good quality meat. They also have a varied selection of "exotic" meats. I was here once because I wanted to cook hasenpfeffer for a special birthday boy. The butcher was super friendly and really helpful. I had never cooked rabbit before and he explained that it was rather easy and gave me  a basic recipe. He also cut up the rabbit for me so I didn't have to worry about that once I got it home. The last time I was there I was looking for chicken liver. I wanted to get some better than Foster's quality chicken liver. Again, the butcher was really helpful. I even asked for a bag of ice so I could keep the meat cold while I took it home and the butcher was happy to make that happen for me. This is the only place I know where you can also find bison steak. One of these days I'm going to have to experiment with that.
author: Daisy S.

description:
Okay, so this will be a very biased review as I've only had the sausages here.  But that's the only reason you need!

I promised a friend who was raving about this place that I would bring a selection of sausages to his bbq.  Off the top of my head I got the chicken cilantro, lamb, irish (corned beef, potatoes), pork/duck and wild boar.  All were Golden Gate home made sausages. I thought they were all good but my favorite was the Wild Boar.

However, I fail to mention the best part - the breakfast pork sausages (chipolatas).  Perfect!  I found any this good since leaving the land of bangers and mash.

I admit, my experience with home made sausage is limited to my dad's venison sausage and Bi-Rite.  I've never been able to find my dad's venison sausage anywhere.  And as much as I usually like Bi-Rite's food (ignoring price), their home made sausages are not very good.  In fact, after getting the breakfast sausages there, we ended up throwing them out because no one wanted to eat them.
author: Jean K.

description:
Went here to meet up with some friends during our annual snowboarding trip (we spent the weekend in SF then headed to Tahoe).  

I only had a hot dog but damn, did that hot dog leave an impression!  It's part of a butcher shop so the meat is as fresh as it can be and you can't beat the price!!! You definitely get more then what you pay for... 

The next time I'm in SF, I'm definitely coming here again...
author: Jun C.

description:
Decided to come here for lunch and some shopping. It's always fun to combine the two, but it depends on the order. If you shop before eating, you tend to buy more and vice versa. We ate first, so we didn't go crazy at the butcher stand.

I got the half rotisserie chicken with the roasted potato side. The chicken was really tender, even the white meat part. I could've done without the potatoes, they were way too big for me, BUT they were done well. The potato was cooked perfectly, so you didn't get the hard parts in the potato. I didn't even need a knife eating it.

Afterwards, I went to the butcher counter. I decided on the ribeye because the marbling looked awesome. In Philadelphia, I like going to my butcher in the Reading Terminal. Although, I miss that counter, I think this one may suffice about half the counter. They do not have many choices here, but the meat looks fresh and the staff is super friendly. The price is also higher, so we'll see how it tastes tonight!
author: Stephanie Y.

description: I couldn't decide on what to eat in the Ferry Building and saw the meats in the counter, they looked yummy. I got the hot pastrami sammy and the meat was so flavorful. The mustard on the tasty hearty roll was a perfect touch. Simple good food!
author: Karen T.

description:
I don't like to give negative reviews, but...I just need to after my ruined lunch today :(

I simply ordered a side of pulled pork, and then picked up some veggies at the farmers market to make a salad at the office. I got back, excited to try what looked like delicious pulled pork. It wasn't. It was probably 60+% fat and the actual meat was really dry. I picked out one chunk of fat/skin that is like a 3" triangle. I love pork fat, but there's a place, a time and a better coooking method. Never again!

The chick working the counter wasn't particularly friendly to me, and when the gentleman behind me asked about the sandwiches they offer, and whether she could modify them for his young children (who were looking desparately hungry...), she simply said "No".  

Yea, we get it, tourists can be aggravating...but, maybe not the best idea to work in a place that attracts them year round... ijs...
author: Jen C.

description:
$2 for a wonderfully delicious, savory, perfect spicy sausage on a stick.  Does life get any better than this?

I'm serious.  The sausage is not too spicy, but spicy enough to give it that slap to your tastebuds.  It's not too greasy.  It's just the right size for a snack.  It's quick.  It's even portable, and napkins are optional.

$2 can't buy you much in this city, but it can buy you this little piece of heaven on a stick.
author: Tori S.

description:
Love this store for the sheer variety of top meats. You can get just about anything, and if they don't have it, they'll order it. That includes Goose Livers for foie gras, which are oh-so-hard to get in politically correct city.

It's not cheap, but then you're buying top quality meat. No corn-fed antibiotic-stuffed animal products here, and that's why I love it so.
author: Mathew L.

description:
Golden Gate Meat Company chronicles Part 7 in the saga "Stephanie Takes Over the Ferry Building, One Bourgeois Boutique at a Time." In Part 6 we had Delica rf1 http://www.yelp.com/biz/delica-rf-1-san-francisco#hrid:E7sbFPgZ2TZF0zFbI_AKRA now what do we say about Golden Gate?

If you want a full standing rib roast, wonderful lamb shank, veal, sausages or gourmet cuts  of your favorite steak, Golden Gate meat company is the place to go. I've been there in the past to purchase from their butchers section and have never been disappointed. Though I strongly prefer Molinari for my cured meats, I do love the selection at Golden Gate.

On Friday, I decided to purchase from their prepared foods section for lunch. I went in intending to get a pastrami sandwich, but after discovering that it consisted of pastrami and "mustard, if you want" I was less intrigued. I like some vegetables on my sandwiches, not just slices of meat and bread.

So instead, I purchased a turkey pot pie. The crust was flakey but there wasn't nearly enough turkey for my liking. The pie tin was primarily full of over-salted gravy without the veggies or meat like I expected from golden gate. It was $6 for a very filling pot pie, and with sandwiches at $8 it's probably still the cheapest lunch in the Ferry Building, but I would rather pay a little extra for my lunch and get something exceptional instead of mediocre prepared food from Golden Gate.

They're still a 4 star place for their selection of meats, but I won't be going back there for prepared lunches in the future.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Large selection of meat, ranging from chicken, turkey, beef and everything in between.

The store front is confusing if you are in the ferry building.  The sign that says "Golden Gate Meat Company" shows a store front, but to actually get to the meat counter, you need to go around through the grocery store.

What I really appreciate about Golden Gate Meat Company is their full disclosure of where their meat comes from.

Previously vegetarian, I started eating meat again after 6 years but deciding to only eat from locally sourced, sustainable establishments.

Golden Gate provides plenty of information of where their meat comes from and how their animals are treated.

It's a little more on the expensive side, but I would rather shop at a place that supplies sustainably sourced meat and a local business than a big box supermarket.
author: Kameron K.

description:
As Barbara Streisand sang, "The Main Event," what she was really thinking about was this place for holiday meals.

Three time's the charm in my annual organic turkey purchase.  So good were the last two years, I decided on a bigger bird this year (16 lbs), because I want some LEFTOVERS! 

Just order (in person or I think even by phone), the kind of bird you want (they will tell you pricing and size) and decide on a pick up date.  For Thanksgiving, the mother of all feasts, I usually call at the beginning of November to ensure my order.  The staff  is also very friendly and knowledgeable about their goods.

Gobble, gobble.
author: Jen L.

description:
I finished work early one day and took Bart into the city. So I walked to the Ferry Building and not too much was open at 730am.  But GGM was and they had a breakfast sandwich, 2 to chose from a Steak and Egg or Bacon and Egg.  

The steak and eggs for 7.99 was huge!  On a hamburger bun, the bun was very soft and fresh.  The steak was sliced thin, moist and flavorful.  The egg I think was fried ot scrambled.  But either way it was delish.  

Next time I will buy some sausages to make Jambalya.
author: Erika G.

description: Good place to get some hard to get exotic meats. They have venison. Yay!
author: Kenson K.

description:
UPDATED:  Every Thursday is a breaded chicken sandwich with a blue cheese sauce.  Great portions and very tasty.  Fridays they have Italian Sausage sandwiches and my coworker and I are trying to figure out what they have Mondays and Tuesdays.  You can't go wrong with these guys.

Every Wednesday (including today) I go to the Ferry Building and get the Skirt Steak Sandwich from GGM.  It's one of the better steak sandwiches I have had.  It's really straightforward:  Acme roll, grilled skirt steak with salt and pepper and natural juices, sauteed onions and mushrooms and an awesome horseradish sauce.  $7.50 and only available on Wednesdays.  Haven't tried anything else, but I heard the BBQ pulled pork and the sausage on a stick are winners.
author: Josh L.

description:
I was here and I saw this sign "wild boar".

I haven't tried wild boar before so I was curious. 

There's a lady infront who keeps staring at me while I'm online. When it's my time to order, I said, I'll try the wild boar.

She started to look at me intensely and smiled like flirting and slipped her business card to my hand (errr... I don't want to be rude eh?).

I guess it's sexy when a guy orders a wild boar???

Going back to the wild boar... I think it's ok - kind a gamey (or gamy). It tasted like pork and beans. Nohing spectacular. I like their selections though, I was not that hungry.

About the calling card, I threw it out... I'm sorry I'm already taken haha!
author: Thigh C.

description:
Merguez, people... they have merguez!!!!

Oh my god I love the Golden Gate Meat Company.   I'm not a huge meat junky but I swear this place does me in every time I walk past their long counter displaying a vast array of succulent meats.   

So they have merguez, which is, for those of you that don't know, a spicy red sausage made from lamb.  Very popular in North Africa, I've had the opportunity to taste it many times in France, where it is also quite readily available.   What's the best way to serve it, Dave?  Get a fresh sweet baguette, grill the merguez as well as the bread.   Now serve the merguez on the toasted bread, very similar to a hot dog.  Lather with mayonnaise to cool off the spiciness.   I know it sounds gross, but you can't bash it 'till you've tried it!

Golden Gate Meats also serves some beautiful veal chops... We're talking serious money being spent here, but oh so worth it...  My wife made their veal chops and accompanied it with some mushroom risotto as well as some sort of a fig sauce...  damn... I just salivated all over the keyboard again!

Ok, anyway it'll cost you, but the meats you buy here are out of this world!   Also they sell their meat rubs in jars... Buy those too as they really help break down tough meats before you throw them on the grill.
author: David O.

description:
This place has kick ass Pastrami.  It ain't as good as Katz's in NYC, however, it is one of the best in SF.  The real deal here is actually the meatloaf, which is to die for.  It has a crunchy crust that goes great with a side of Macaroni and Cheese.  Ok, Atkins it ain't.  However, it might be better than sex(with some people:-)

Update: If you like a good steak then you must try their aged NY steak.  It is exquisitely delicious.  I may never buy steak from Costco again :-)  I bought a 1/2 pound-er today just to try it and I am just amazed at how great it is, so creamy and Delicious with an earthy taste, it was exceedingly tender.  I LOVE THIS PLACE.

warning: today's pastrami was a little dry and their meatloaf was kind of Grey in color.  However, their stuff is still kick ass.  Even with this lapse.
author: Jim J.

description:
This review is for the hot prepared foods only...

Great place to pickup dinner for the fam if you don't feel like cooking, but still want a decent meal.

Awesome place to stop for lunch when you're in the neighborhood.

pot pie = amazing 
bbq beef sandwich = big and delicious
mac & cheese = to die for
author: Lindsay C.

description: I am a serious amateur chef and the most important ingredients to my cooking are uncompromising ingredients.  Golden Gate purveys some of the finest proteins in the country, with fair prices and a superior selection - with fabulous, family friendly and neighborhood oriented service.  They are simply the best and I look forward to every opportunity I have to find something great to cook. CB
author: Christopher B.

description:
Well alrighty then, let's talk POT PIE!

I spied chicken pot pie a couple for sale here a couple weeks ago and gave it a try.  Delicious!  The chicken was moist and tender and, like the potatoes and veggies, nice and chunky.  There was also a good meat-to-potatoes ratio in my pie.  And the crust?  A full pie crust - not just the top.  Buttery and crusty, just the way I like my pie crusts.

Bottom line:  a winner :)

I've also tried their beef pot pie with meat just as tender and moist, but I kind of liked the chicken pot pie much better.  Glad to have finally stopped by here.  It's often passed over for the more trafficked spots nearby.  But worth it if you want nice slow-cooked meaty meals.
author: Eileen P.

description: Can't go wrong for lunch here. Everything I've tried has been filling and tasty. My go to is the Thursday breaded chicken sandwich. Two generous portions of chicken accompanied with either blue cheese dressing or barbecue sauce (do the blue cheese) and peppers and onions. The lunch options rotate as well, which means you might get lucky like I did and cash in on some bacon-wrapped filet well below market price. Meatloaf and chicken pot pie are both good bets as well
author: Taylor C.

description:
Another example of you get what you pay for.

Most of the time I special order my stuff from them. Their prime rib roast is aged for four weeks, trimmed (and that means removing the meat from the bone to get that central vein of fat out and then reattaching it with twine) and then a thick cap of caul fat is heated and draped over the top. Just beautiful and it shows the work done.

This year I bought a couple of geese from them and they are very good at communicating to me what the sizes are, what the price per pound, where the meat comes from, etc. Just very good, honest, and friendly customer service.
author: Horns D.

description:
Um, wow. REALLY???

I wrote a review a few weeks ago about how this business is HOMOPHOBIC. And I just noticed that somehow they deleted my review (probably had Yelp delete it). WHAT BULLSHIT. I'm pretty outraged. It just goes to show how guilty these bottom feeders really are. They obviously want to cover up their shit. This company is shady, reeking of bullshit, and filled to the brim with overt hatred.

So, I am posting again! AND I will keep on re-posting, so delete away bigots!

IF YOU SUPPORT LGBT AND HUMAN RIGHTS, DO NOT GIVE THIS COMPANY YOUR PATRONAGE.

My girlfriend worked here, until they fired her FOR BEING GAY. This is not slander, this is what actually happened. Please take a moment and read exactly what happened to her:

"This past Saturday, March 5th 2011, after two months at my job at Golden Gate Meat Company, I was fired, the very day after I "came out" at work and introduced my girlfriend to my co-worker. This co-worker had made anti-gay remarks in front of me in the past. On my last day on the job, my boss asked me to leave early and said she needed to speak to me. She walked me to the back room and without any explanation immediately said "We have to let you go." and handed me my last check and some tip money. I was shocked and didn't know what to say. I asked her if I had done something wrong and she told me, "You're not a good fit. It's just not working out." She didn't apologize or convey any empathy towards me whatsoever. The next thing she said was "Could you go ahead and leave your work shirt behind?" I couldn't because I had no undershirt. I don't know whether to pursue a legal case or what, since I was let go before the end of my 90 day probation period. I was never given any indication that my work performance was lacking. I'm a good worker and a friendly employee, and never did anything to deserve this kind of disrespectful, cruel, and dismissive treatment. The co-worker who made anti-gay remarks since the second day I had been working there, happens to be my boss' niece. I believe she either made up a story about me to her aunt, or she straight out told her I was gay and/or that she didn't want me working there, and that was the end of my job. A comment she made shortly after I began working there, was concerning two men who were greeting each other in front of our store. We were talking and as they approached each other she asked me if they had kissed. I said "No, why? Do you know them?" and she responded "No, I just don't want to see that." I was shocked by her comment, and immediately became fearful for my job there. I never lied or denied being a lesbian. The question never arose, since she was never very friendly towards me anyway. I've never dealt with discrimination such as this. I feel completely crushed and confused. All I can ask people to do at this point, is to not give Golden Gate Meat Company your patronage. And if possible, please help me get the word out further on this homophobic company. 

Thank you for reading."

.
author: Betsy W.

description:
There we were wandering around the Ferry Building waiting for our tour to start, and guess what is open at 8 in the morning, this is it. 
While we only had a couple of their breakfast sandwiches, I was impressed with their selection of meats. Friendly helpful staff, nice place.
author: Bill D.

description:
I've experienced GG Meat Co. strictly as a butcher shop where I find the staff to be knowledgeable and courteous and the selection to be the best in the city.  GG is, in the store itself, an average shop.  The 'fourth star' is for the selection they are able to order (and will) and  have available the next day.  Anyone who has traveled in the central US has probably noticed there are many cuts that people in the west just don't seem to appreciate.  Whether brisket, beef-back ribs, or more exotic items, GG can have a volume available for you by tomorrow.  

GG is expensive though like everything else in the Ferry building.  It's just as easy to get to Trader Joe's where pork baby-back ribs are usually available at 1/5th the cost.  After they are rubbed and roasted for 7 hours I can't taste the difference and would rather have acquired 5x the ribs for the same price- invite 5 more friends to dinner!  That said, I probably order from GG every other month and spend between $50 and $75 on each order.  It's always something that wasn't available anywhere else and GG always makes it easy.
author: David H.

description: I always went to the Golden Gate Meat Company for their chicken and their pizza.  Yeah, it's an odd combo I know.  The fact that you can get a whole chicken for $6.99 in the FiDi for lunch is a deal, or you can opt for half a chicken with potatoes and veggies for the same price.  Their pizza is ok, nothing to really brag about, but for me it complimented their chicken very well.  It's a great lunch spot if you're looking for something to eat in the Ferry Building.
author: Rodney H.

description: I am not well-versed in terms of SF butchers but for my money GGMC does a great job. If you're willing to dodge the crazy mob of tourists that swarm the ferry building this is a great choice. I don't know much about the different cuts of meat so the awesome customer service is much appreciated. Whoever is helping us has always been so patient answering questions and even offering recipe advice.  I'm not sure about price, it's awfully pricy but I guess it's to be expected at the ferry building. Every piece of meat that I've gotten here has been amazing, I especially recommend the rack of lamb.
author: Kate N.

description: It's hard to decide on a place to eat in the Ferry building when you're super hungry and can't be bothered to wait very long for your food.  Also because you're kinda sweaty and gross (having biked and climbed for the last 5 hours) so sitting down and drinking a bottle of wine and eating fancy cheeses doesn't seem quite right either.  Golden Gate Meat Company was perfect because service was fast, the prices very reasonable and they even had seating.  I got the pulled chicken sandwich which was pretty tasty and the boy got his chicken salad which he'd been craving all afternoon.  While it won't be a destination next time we're at the Ferry building, it's definitely a dependable place for a quick bite.
author: Kathleen W.

description:
Today I got the macaroni and cheese.
Today my macaroni and cheese was sort of pink.
Cheese should not be pink.
author: Lauren S.

description:
in the words of guy, winner winner wild boar dinner.

i got certified in cpr today, so i decided, what better way to celebrate than to head down to the ferry building saturday farmers' market and walk around. i bought nothing, of course, due to the insane prices for produce, but my brother and i did spend some cash on prepared food. he had korean tacos from namu while i dove into a terrible bean burrito from mijita (check my review about that) and some fantastic wild board chili with roasted peppers from golden gate meat.

the chili was supposed to be $5 for a tub, but they only charged me $4 (score!). the liquid was a violent red shade, the best, and at first i thought the boar would be tough, but it was ground, soft, and succulent. my only complaints would be that there was too much meat and not enough chili ingredients (beans, peppers, veggies) and it was a bit too salty, but the chili tasted pretty good otherwise (and it was not too greasy, always a plus), especially on a cold, blustery sf day. it turned out to have a very mild latent kick, but everything about this chili was very good. i'm glad i waited this long to try golden gate meat, as i had good news come out of this place for quite some time. i also shucked a massive oyster a few shops down for $1.50. it was sooo fresh and briny.
author: Danny C.

description:
BBQ chicken sandwich rocks my world.

Chicken chili tastes too much like red peppers.
author: L B.

description: Given that this place is a 'meat company' I shouldn't have been all that surprised that my barbecue pork sandwich had two ingredients: barbecue pork and bread. Granted it was a ton of tasty pork, but I like to at least pretend that my sandwiches are healthy by adding some lettuce and tomatoes.
author: Wing Y.

description: Friendly, knowledgeable butchers. Great selection. Fresh offerings. Casual place to sit and grab lunch, or a snack from the adjacent market.
author: Maurice R.

description: Golden Gate Meat Company pulled through for me today. After we got snubbed by Jim's Wholesale in Milpitas, CA because they refused to honor their hours, we scrambled to find another meat company who could put together a big order with meats that cannot be found just anywhere. Fortunately for us, Golden Gate Meat Company was professional, courteous, and obviously cared about their customers which seem to be qualities sorely lacking in other meat companies. Thanks Golden Gate Meat Company! You made our day.
author: Deo T.

description:
I'm not a vegan, but that doesn't mean I think it's ok to torture cattle by feeding them grain that makes them sick and hormones that make them grow at double speed, and packing them in like sardines on vermin and microbe infested feed lots to stand around all day in their own manure trying in futility to swat all the flies off themselves with their notably NON-prehensile tails.  It's a crime what is done to the cattle that supply most of the beef people eat in this country.

I grew up on a dairy farm in Wisconsin.  We'd slaughter a calf once a year and eat it all year long.  The cattle grazed in pastures.  On average, I think there was about an acre of pasture per head.  In bad weather, they ate alfalfa that was grown right on the farm.  They were healthy.  They grew slowly.  They lived well.   They tasted delicious.  Ditto our lambs and pigs.

Golden Gate Meat Company is one of the best butcher shops in town.  I doubt all the animals that gave up the meats that GGMC sells had lives quite as idyllic as the animals I ate as a kid.  But they've got an impressive selection of grass-fed and organic meats, nonetheless.  

But I digress.  The real reason I go here?  Their deli counter sells a house-made beef pot pie that I just love.  $6 lunch.  Woot!
author: Joe C.

description: Review only for the spicy sausage on a stick! Soooo good...meaty sausage for only $2. Would go great in a sandwich w/ mozzarella cheese - but I think I can eat several while just walking from vendor to vendor.
author: Calvin Y.

description:
The meat is great. But most of all I love these guys. And here's why. (stop reading now if you don't care about irrelevant stories.)

One Saturday I was preparing for my turn to do Roommate Dinner Night. And I rarely do cheap. So I had hatched this plan to do ribs and if I am going to go for a fairly expensive cut of meat (I'm thinking actually quantity you can eat vs. not) I thought why not go for something humanely raised or grass fed or some such hippie shit that makes the meal cost 25% more. 

So I go from stall to stall at the Farmers Market and then the Embarcadero Building asking for pork ribs to no avail. And then I thought I would try Golden Gate Meats. But get in their quick because those baby backs seem to be going fast!

Lo and behold, the HOTTEST MEN are working so I bat my eyes and ask the Hot Butcher if they have baby back ribs.

HB: "Yeah, how many do you want?"
Me: "Whatever you have" (remember, this is at least my third try)
HB: "No, how many do you want?"
Me: "How much do you have?"
HB: "How much do you need?"
Me: "I need alot"
HB: "How much is alot?"
Me: "7lbs"
HB: "OK then" (cuts & gives me 7lbs of ribs) "There you go hon. Good thing I didn't give you everything we got. Because we have 50 lbs. I can totally give you more though!"

And all of this with the subtle teasing that I have gotten used to from hot guys that I never got in high school that I have grown to love so much. Who cares if you are way out of my league! You're hot & are joking with me! I'll come back to get meat from you anytime!

Pun completely intended!
author: Alexis B.

description:
If you love stuffing your mouth with delicious hot meat, this is definitely your spot.

Imagine a salad buffet at the most veganized place you can imagine.  Now inverse it.  There you go - rotisserie chickens rolling along, chicken pot pies, hot pastrami, meat stews, meat pastes, MEAT-ON-A-STICK, and on and on.  I think the only non-meat items I saw were the mac-and-cheese and the small tray of potatos and vegetables (garnish), but they were easily dwarfed by the selection of meat foods.

It's a small joint, so walking through the Ferry Building you might miss it, but if you stop for more than a moment you'll see the fine selection of meat-centric meals waiting to satisfy your luncheon needs.

I had the Pastrami (with cheese, no mustard - sorry NYC heritage!) and mac and cheese.  Both were delicious and I couldn't even come close to finishing them.  $10 total.  I grabbed one of their lemonade cups and it was also unusually delicious (that was $1.50 extra, but perfect for the meal).

Best of all, for a OCD hand person such as myself, they have a bin of handi-wipes right at the register!  That pushed them from 4 to 5 stars.

There's no lack of good food at the ferry building, all of it expensive, but for a walkaway ten spot this is a must-visit.
author: Matt H.

description:
It's kind of a mixed bag at this upscale convenience store in the heart of the gourmet food court -- there are the good and the not quite so good features.  

The good: the location, the ample table seating, the quality meats, the conveniently located snacks and drinks at your fingertips, and the hot food counter out in the concourse serving up breakfast sandwiches, sausage-on-a-stick, pizza, meatloaf, and a variety of hot sandwiches.

The great: the best thing here is the hot pastrami sandwich.  It is HUGE.  Served on a fresh sweet french roll from Acme next door, squirted with spicy deli mustard, the fresh slices are pulled right out of their own au jus and stuffed into the bread.  Must be a pound of meat on there and they don't bother weighing it or anything.  The hot meat girl wraps it up in foil paper and you're good to go for 6 bucks.  

The not quite so good: I've tried a number of other things here, none of which were as good as the pastrami, that's why I can't give this deli and butcher shop a full battery of stars.  The ribeye steak wasn't as tender as a good ribeye should be, the chicken pot pie was mostly crust and a little skimpy on the filling, the pizza had little chunks of fatty diced pork on it and was far from tasty, and the ground chuck is nothing too out of the ordinary, giving my burger an unwanted mealy texture. 

Anyhow, go for the pastrami.  That's a sure thing.
author: Rick H.

description:
Nice people, great meat.

If they don't have it, they will cut if for you. If they still don't have it, they will order it for you. Anything. Squab, buffalo, Wagyu beef, a dozen geese - you just have to ask.

Golden Gate is a great place to start the next time you are planning to reenact Babette's feast.
author: H G.

description:
This is review is also for the hot prepared food only, but is completely opposite the previous review. I want to go for lunch, I go out hoping to eat some meat on a nice sunny Friday afternoon, I do not check my android for any recommendations and fall for the name.....how bad could be the meat at a place named meat company !! Well guess what, if you are looking for dessert made of barbeque beef, this is the perfect place. I have had sweet bbq sauce and I have had sweeter bbq sauce, but if the sauce is made of sugar syrup, I think its no longer a bbq sauce but a dessert dressing. The meat was not bad in itself, it could have been so much better if paired with the right sauce instead of a very sweet liquid with no condiments !

Well, thats not the end of it though or actually not the start, even before you have tasted your food, the cashier girl gives you a taste of her attitude. Smiling at customers who are paying almost $10 for lunch might just get you some tips in that empty tip jar, or probably she was practicing for her poker night. So if you are looking for a place that makes you feel unwanted since you are disturbing the cashiers peace by making her take your payment, this will be at the top of the otherwise very friendly shops at Ferry Building market place.
author: Varun G.

description:
*4.5 stars*

I've only been here once and had the beef pot pie.  Yummm yeah!  Delicious!  Also had a bite of the chicken pot pie and the pizza...  I prefered the beef to the chicken pot pie.  Little C didn't care for the pizza, but he's going on 4 years so...  but his mommy said he's not much of a pizza fan to begin with.  I thought it looked better than it tasted.  Oh well.  I'll just stick to the beef pot pies for now.
author: Christine T.

description:
Rick H. - Thanks for the oh-so delicious pastrami!

Matt H. - Thanks for the cold mac'n'cheese you didn't know you were sharing.

It's all about quality, not quantity man. Make sure that you go with friends so you can mooch the great tasting grub for free :o)

PS - We were also able to bring outside food into their little sanctuary despite the signs on the table that specifically mentioned no outside food.  I guess they could tell that we had special Yelper status and that no rules apply to us. :o)
author: Aim E.

description: Great place! We got some wild boar! Will update after we make a gulash!
author: Nobbi L.

description:
I like the BBQ pork sandwich.  Substantial meat portion.  Good fresh crunchy roll.  Not too sweet and not too fatty.
The ferry building at lunch time during the week is a real madhouse with many of the places dealing with crazy lines which I try to avoid, but I'll wait in a line, not a long one for one of these sandwiches.
Good, not great, but there when you're craving a pork sandwich.
author: Kev M.

description:
A little more than a week after reconnecting myself with the world's best pastrami (http://www.yelp.com/biz/V7lXZKBDzScDeGB8JmnzSA?hrid=VHkRKx_fOofaIjRw-vKxwQ) in New York City, I decided to give the pastrami at Golden Gate Meat Company a try to see how it compared. 

I met Sooj O. in the Ferry Building for what we'd dubbed our Pastrami and Cupcakes lunch (we went to Miette for dessert). We split a huge pastrami sandwich with dijon mustard on a French roll. The pastrami was pretty good with an almost bacon-like flavor, but it didn't melt in my mouth and it lacked the black peppery crust of the pastrami I really love. 

But for $9 ($7 for the sandwich and $1 each for bottled water), it sure is a lot cheaper than flying to New York.
author: Arnold G.

description:
I went to the Ferry Building on my lunch break to pick up items for a nosh plate: meats, cheeses, fruit, salad and bread. Safeway was closer, but I wanted some quality ingredients, so I went the extra distance. I stopped in the Golden Gate Meat Company for the animal products.

Good choice! The selection of meats there is insane. You can find more options for cheese at Cowgirl Creamery in the same building, but they had a good 8-10 to choose from. 

Once the flighty guy in front of me quit flitting about trying to make up his mind, I was promptly helped by an eager staff member whose eyes lit up when I asked if he had prosciutto. He pulled out a hunk of it, showed me the cross cut and told me it was delicious. I believed him, and ordered a quarter pound. I also selected salami, and he recommended a wine cured one. When I ordered a half pound of it he informed me that would be 60-80 slices, which was way more than I needed. I cut my order in half, so thanks to him I saved some money. 

I got my cheese and my meats and sidled over to the register where the lady behind it remarked on how great my choices were. She wasn't wrong. The kind guy behind the counter sliced thinly some of the best tasting salami I've ever put in my mouth and the cheddar was divine. The quality ingredients made for an awesome indoor picnic with my boyfriend, and I can't wait to go back to try some of their other more exotic options.

A+++++++++  WOULD SHOP AGAIN
author: Brittney G.

description: Came here after seeing the favorable reviews of pastrami. The pastrami here is really sub par. Worse than fast food pastrami in LA (The Hat). Reinforces my belief that pastrami in SF is to be avoided, wise sons deli is the only place for legit LA/NYC caliber pastrami in SF
author: David Z.

description:
NOTE: This review is written by a former vegetarian. That's right - from age 14 to age 24 I ate NO red meat, poultry, or fish. 


Finding Golden Gate Meat Company was like finding the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow. Where else in the city can you purchase elk and quail regularly? I like to eat traditionally so the "wilder" my meat is the more excited I am about eating it. I've made pate from both their chicken livers and their calf livers, and both batches turned out wonderfully. And as a bonus they are located in the Ferry Building which is my favorite place in the city.
author: Stephanie S.

description: Don't come here to eat but I occasionally shop here for meat, I LOVE the wild boar and beer sausages! I like that the place looks clean, and the meat is fresh, delicious, and unpacked. The service is also really good and the staff is friendly and have made some good suggestions. I got complimentary spices once that were really amazing.
author: Kina M.

description:
I spent too much time reading Ed M's awesome review to write a long one of my own.  Suffice it to say that in spite of the Ferry Building prices, the butcher counter here won me over with its awesome selection and easily navigable presentation (no yuppie bells and whistles, like waving jams and demi-glaces in your face).  I especially like the sausage selection--got me a few of the duck-pork links for my baked rigatoni.  Unique flavor, but it was packed a little loose--maybe cause they're cramming all those pine nuts and other goodies in there?

I made a mental note to grab a breakfast sandwich from here someday--it's got to be a better deal than the Acme sandwiches, right?

***Update*** Still haven't had the breakfast sandwich, but I am addicted to their $8.60/lb European Bacon.  If you're into Twinings, Brown Sauce, and crumpets, your breakfast will not be complete without it, and it's the best deal in town AFAIK.
author: Wes M.

description:
Huge Fan! I buy all my meats here. The meat quality is outstanding. They have knowledgeable butchers and they're all friendly. 

Super awesome customer service given every time I come. Love it!!!
author: Yelp T.

description:
GOD I LOVE MEAT. 

Sometimes, when I'm by a really delectible meat counter such as this, I fantasize about having my own butcher in my basement.  You know, a strong man with access to lots of meat, just standing there patiently wrapped in his white, starched outfit, waiting for me to decide what kind of meat I want to feast on TONIGHT!!??

Um I just kinds of scared myself there.  Tee Hee (nervous laugh) 

But no truely, when I am done purchasing my totally organic, dye free laundry soap and Dr. Bronner's soap for the other parts in the house that must be cleaned (yes, including my own), I saunter on back to the meat department here and take my little, ol' sweet time selecting what animal carcus I will devour this evening.  I have recently purchased a New York strip, bone in pork chops and some free range (run chicken run) chicken thighs and they have all pleased me to lip smacking end. 

So, I say, hell to Whole Foods and their F*&KING $20 lbs of meat, head on over to Golden Gate and make Momma proud.  I'll be that blond chick eyeballing the lamb chops the way some chicks drool over US Weekly.  Really.
author: Claire C.

description:
I'm not a big meat eater, but when I do eat meat, I want it to be BIG and I wanted it to be TASTY.  GGMC takes care of me in both categories.

I stopped by yesterday to pick up some items for the grill, and spent a bit of time browsing the meat case, which was chock-full of impressive roasts, steaks, chops, organ meats, sausages - you name it!  I choose a couple of different types of sausage - the pork/duck combo and a french one (can't remember the name) that was pork with onions, garlic and lots of spices.  We grilled 'em all up and they were just fabulous!

Five stars for BIG and TASTY meat!
author: .Hon H.

description: This place has very good food and their prices are very reasonable.  I love their rotisserie chicken plate with potatoes and veggies for only $6!! Well it was $6 just double checked and it's $7.50 now, what's this world coming to?  I've also tried their pulled chicken sandwich which came with only mustard, it was alright I'm guessing they're pulled pork is amazing! They are not greedy with the chicken either, my sandwich was FAT! They also sell pot pies here :) mmm mmm gotta love pot pies.  I would also recommend their chicken soup it's very delicious and cheap $3 (that could of went up too) and you're set for lunch.  Great place for lunch.
author: Christina O.

description:
Great selection of meats... 
Fantastic selections of gohgi...
Massive selections of carne...
Stupendous selections of meso...
First-rate selections of daging...
Ridiculous selections of liha...
Sensational selections of das fleisch...
Yummy selections of kjott...
Numerous selections of vlees...

You get the point right?
author: Jen D.

description:
While visiting the bay area we stopped at the Golden Gate Meat Company to grab a quick bagel. What a mistake. The bagel itself was pretty good, but..........they gave me a little sauce cup of cream cheese, which would have been a marginal amount, except there were air voids in the sauce cup, decreasing the amount by probably 1/3.
I asked the girl at the counter if I could get one that had no air voids. She called the manager who after much back and forth gave me one that had a little more cream cheese.
My wife had asked for bagel with butter. She received one (1) little patty of butter, when we asked for butter for the other half we were told that if would cost $0.25 additional  Manager comes out again, we asked to speak to the owner, and he very smugly said that it would do no good as the owner was his father-in-law.. We sent to another food vendor and got another patty of butter for free. I ran a business for 30 years and the customer is always right up to a reasonable extent. The son in law, must surely been the same guy who wanted to charge $0.15 for a pack of salt, which by the way, just for kicks when I was at a market the next day  buying  some water,I asked how much salt packs cost, and the  guy gave me three packs gratis.
 
I am sure this place had good meats even if a little pricey, but the son in law will manage to destroy the business. My wife and I revel in, going back to a business where people  treated discourteously or stupidly (the son in law) and see that it has closed.
author: Joe N.

description:
Sometimes all you want is a nice, big, juicy sandwich for lunch and the BBQ beef sandwich at Golden Gate Meat Co. certainly fits the bill.  Their stand may not look all that appetizing, but all you have to do to realize that they're using high quality meats is to visit their meat counter and see how much they're charging for their products.

I was tempted by their pastrami, but I decided on their BBQ Beef sandwich instead.  At $8, you get a huge sandwich with a lot of thinly sliced, tender beef and tangy BBQ sauce.  You will definitely need the wet naps they give you- the sauce will run all over your hands and mouth as you eat and its not going to look real nice back at the office if you come back with a BBQ sauce'd face.  Definitely make sure you're not wearing anything white unless you don't mind little splashes of sauce marring the front of the shirt.  I do wish the BBQ sauce had a little more heat to it, but it was still tasty.  Some caramelized onion would have been good too, but considering that they are a MEAT company, I can see why the sandwich is nothing but meat, bread, and sauce.

4 stars for a great sandwich- I'd most definitely be back to try the pastrami, as well as some of the other menu items.
author: Angela H.

description:
The meat sold here comes from 100% organic cows, free-ranging in fields of honey-scented mist, while being massaged and read inspiring quotes from leaders of the civil rights movement and meditating.  These cows are lovingly cared for for many years, their every need immediately met, their butts lovingly wiped, cuz cows can't reach.

Does the meat taste any better for it?  Actually, no.

I mean, it doesn't taste BAD of anything, but I went so far as to actually do the Pepsi challenge with GGMC's meat (except I substituted their meat for the Pepsi and meat from Yangtze Meat and Fish Market for Coke), and ended up preferring the steak from Yangtze.  Plus, the steak from Yangtze is literally less than half the cost.

Now, Yangtze is located next to the 16th & Mission BART stop instead of in the vaunted Ferry Building, but the whole point here is good meat, right?

Bottom line: GGMC's meat is good, but hella expensive.  You can do better.
author: Ben P.

description: They also make amazing sandwiches. I like the pulled chicken and the bbq pork, which is a little on sweet side, but very tasty! If you're in a hurry, sausage on a stick is the way to go!! MMmmmm-eat!
author: Colleen B.

description:
Ok - so, before I get to the good, lemme just offer this one less than favourable nugget: The sandwich shop portion of this place is not all that great. It's not BAD - but it's very "under a heat lamp" type of food, and considering the quality of the meats from the butcher shop, this was a minor shock to me when I tried 'em out. 

Now the good - and man oh man is it GOOD!

I have committed myself to ONLY purchasing meats of a certain caliber due to personal, political, and health reasons - and in these economic times, that can sometimes be a pain in the butt - but I try and do my part. 

Golden Gate Meat Co. has been a godsend to me. They have some of the FINEST cuts of meat available for consumption in the city (short of going to Harris Steak House or something similar). But there's more - the service is impeccable, the variety is pretty amazing, and the prices (for the quality you get) is nothing short of spectacular. 

Not only do they have all the classic cuts you'd want, but you can get bulk orders, interesting little wild game, and some of the best homemade sausages I have ever had.  Seriously - the venison sausage was amazing, the rabbit sausage, even the "buffalo wing" sausage (*drool*) have been out of this world.

Any serious foodie worth his/her salt will stop pinching their pennies and getting some craptastic "steak" from places like Safeway, and save up for a proper, grass fed cut of meat from GG Meat Co. 

Go try 'em out and tell me I' m wrong - I dare ya!
author: Marco M.

description:
As part of our Pastrami and Cupcake lunch (followed up by shopping at Fog City News for chocolate...if you can believe it...we are all about the nonstop food.  If I didn't have to return to work, I am sure we would have proceeded to even more food), Arnold G. and I shared a pastrami sandwich from the Golden Gate Meat Company.  Given the size of the sandwich, it's actually a bargain at $7.  

The pastrami was pretty good, and hot which, in my opinion, is key to either a pastrami or a corned beef sandwich experience.  There were two things I would have liked to have changed: I would have enjoyed a more robust mustard, probably the more grainy mustard that has a stronger taste, and rye bread.  Oddly enough, despite San Francisco's amazing array of artisanal bread bakeries, I have a hard time finding traditional Jewish and Eastern European breads.  And while the French roll for the pastrami was delicious....pastrami should be on rye.

Oh, they also sell sausage on the stick.
author: Sooj O.

description:
MEAT MEAT MEAT MEAT MEAT MEAT MEAT!
No Herbivores allowed!!!
This place rocks.  I just don't know which animal to eat when I'm staring at all the meat.  Beef, chicken, and sausage times 10, I just get so confused, I just want to eat it all.  So I tried the french bread pizza.  LOL! I know, I know, this is a meat place, why am I ordering the pizza?  I was also tempted to try the beef pot pie, actually.  Yes, I ordered some spicy sausage with mustard.  Awesome.  It could have been spicier though, but it was quite flavorful nonetheless. 
MEAT MEAT MEAT MEAT!!!
author: Johanan L.

description:
Very disheartening that an upset ex-employee would try to slander such an outstanding established business like Golden Gate Meat.
I have worked across from them for two years now and have nothing but good things to say.They are some of the most customer oriented butchers and staff you will ever meet. Always there to answer any questions, clear up any confusion, and offer outstanding products.
There staff is so friendly and helpful and they are almost always asking you what they can do for you before you even reach the counter.
Sounds like this employee did not fit these high standards. 
So her deciding to blame her losing her job on being gay is unacceptable.
So disgruntled ex-employee don't place blame on Golden Gate Meat, but rather look at yourself, your work ethic and habits, and come to a more realistic conclusion
author: Easy E.

description: The guys here are incredibly friendly, helpful and knowledgeable. I typically experiment cooking with different cuts of lamb meat - stew,roast or bake and they always tell me the right cut, how long it needs to be in for and anything additional if needed.  Also, since I'm somewhat of a newbie cook when it comes red meat, I find the guys here easy to talk to and they give me different ideas to try out. And I also really like their bagels and breakfast sandwich in the mornings too.Definitely check this place out!
author: Sushma Y.

description: We ate lunch at the Ferry Building and decided to buy food from here. It seemed like it had the most variety of all the eateries. We ordered a turkey pot pie & BBQ pork sandwich. The pork sandwich was good, could have used a little more sauce or at least one that had more kick to it. The pot pie was nicely peppered and very tasty. A nice bit of comfort food. I'll come back again and try some of their other offerings. Prices are decent too.
author: Gina Q.

description:
Mmmmmm sausage on a stick, I feel like I am back in Minnesota!  
Except this little wiener costs $6 bucks...now I know am in San Francisco.

It was good though, and organic, which is why its probably worth it.
author: Nilu r.

description: Might be OK if you're just here to buy raw meat. I got a lunch special - skirt steak sandwich-- expecting something really delicious for $9.50. Instead I got a so-so sandwich with medicre bread, tough meat, some onions/mushrooms, not-so-great sauce, and no veggies or other additions (lettuce?? tomatoes?? cheese??) to speak of. The meat was bland and overcooked. Maybe it had some salt on it, but it was hard to tell. I ended up having to go to another place to get more stuff to supplement the sandwich so i could eat it.
author: emily d.

description:
This has become just about the only place I buy meat.  Yes, it is expensive (ok, some would say a rip off), but this is quality stuff.  You can see their steaks dry-aging in a meat locker right in front of your eyes.  The super-nice staff will butcher anything to your exact specifications (which gives them a serious edge over Marin Sun and Prather Ranch, because all of their meat is vacuum-sealed --- I mean, do those guys really expect a girl to hack away at her own pork shoulder?).  And the house-made sausages... those are little tubes of heaven right there.  Over Super Bowl weekend, I picked up a few of the Chicken Wing specimens (that's right, chicken wing-flavored sausages --- genius), and to BF's shock and delight, it was exactly like munching on a wing.  But in sausage form.  Amazing.  (And no, there's no funky artificial stuff in there.  That would be cheating!)

But I can't give five stars just yet.  Because their prepared foods are just not up to snuff (how can the raw goods be so perfect and the cooked stuff so steam table-ish?).  And they do not carry the superlative Hoffman Farms chickens (these are pasture-raised.  It makes a difference).  Come on, Golden Gate, step it up!
author: Melissa B.

description:
The meatloaf has a hunk of cheese inside
and it comes with mixed veg'tables as well
The sausage on a stick is cheap and fast...

---the cheese inside that meatloaf makes it SWELL
author: April D.

description: When I say they have everything, I mean it. For a couple pretty pennies, you can get anything from boar to elk to crocodile. Yeah, everything. They even have smoked meats and more "conventional" ingredients. And how can you forget the service? They found some really nice people to run that shop......
author: Garrett P.

description:
3.14.2007
12:00AM

I'm getting fat.

But I can't help it because this place is on my weekly lunch circuit.  

For $20, I get 2 HUGE pastrami sandos and 3 sausages on a stick.  I don't eat them all of course, the sausages are given away as tokens of gratitude while the sando (at least this day) went to one of my coworkers.  

Tender meat.  Spicy brown mustard.  Moist roll.  

I wish they put grilled onions and sauerkraut on it.
author: William R.

description:
I was here to get a whole chicken to take home when I saw the guy behind the counter make a skirt steak sandwich. What a show: he prepped the roll with some kind of orange-colored sauce, then he piled on large pieces of steak--yes, PILED--and topped it off with sauteed onions and mushrooms. I should have applauded.

Yup, I got one too. Other reviews say it's a Wednesday-only thing.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Definitely worth trying, if you're in the mood for a hearty pork sandwich. Here's the breakdown: 

LUNCH: 
1 BBQ Pork Sandwich, $7
1 Fresh squeezed OJ, $2.50

BBQ Pork: 
The BBQ Pork was a good portion, a good deal in the Ferry Building. There was a lot of BBQ Sauce, and it tasted good. However, although there was a lot of BBQ flavoring, the pork wasn't that fall-off-the-bone softness. It also wasn't infused with flavor and/or well-seasoned, as if it hadn't absorbed all the BBQ sauce. I think the pork itself was a bit bland. Worth trying, but I won't be back for this anytime soon. 3 Stars. 

OJ: 
Not that sweet, or as tasty as some other OJ I've had (in Cambridge, MA @ Au Bon Pain). A bit disappointed, but it helped to sip down the BBQ pork. 2 1/2 Stars. 

Conclusion: 
Good portion, a nice meal for a good price. 

Other Recommendations:
