Go to Mo's in North Beach for a delish BBQ Pork Sandwich.
author: Eric C.

description:
I love how quick you can get your meal here. Yet it is still fresh and tasty.

I had the hot pastrami with dijon mustard. It was quite honestly the BEST pastrami sandwich I've ever had. The meat was tender and juicy, the sandwich was not overly salty and the homemade dijon mustard was great compliment to the sandwich. 
My friend had the breaded chicken breast special sandwich. He liked it. What also looked good was the pork BBQ. Gotta try that next time. 

There may be a line, but wait it out. It moves quick.
author: Danvin R.

description: Ok, it's at the Ferry Building, so the prices are steep. That's the downside, the ONLY downside. Their meat selection is one-of-a-kind and their butchers are truly butchers - not meat packagers like you get at most grocery stores. They know all the cuts, the will handle all special orders and they do it with personality and a sense of humor - even on Saturday when the place is a zoo. My go-to place when the carnivore in me wants to feast.
author: Lefty R.

description:
I've bought nothing but top quality meats here.  Service is great -- and friendly, to boot.  Don't let my cube/minute steak problem deter you from patronizing this excellent shop!

So why just 4 stars and not 5?  I wanted a cube steak and nobody could do one up fresh for me.  In fact the butcher had no idea what it was.  

First he pointed to a flank steak (I still can't figure out why) and then after I described it, even referencing the butcher's tenderizing machine, all he brought back was a piece of round steak on which he'd whaled with a meat mallet 'til it was paper thin.  I forgot it's sometimes also called "minute steak", but should that have mattered?
author: Nancy W.

description:
The sausages are what I stop by here for. The selection is great and the counter help is friendly. I'm sure if I ever branched out to other cuts of meat I would love them just as much.

Also what's great about here is their selection of hot foods, ready to eat. Pot pies, barbecued ribs, soup of the day and, best of all, meat on a stick! It's really a sausage but meat sounds so much catchier. It's meat! On a stick! For $2! Nice. Need a quick hit of protein? You got it.
author: cyndi L.

description:
I get scared at deli counters. I can't help it, I just freeze up and I forget what I was originally there for. Well, that's usually...

Yesterday I went to GGMC because I had decided to make my boyfriend rack of lamb for his birthday dinner.  First off, I should admit I know less about cooking than I do about buying meat, so this was going to be an ambitious project all around! However, the counter guy at GGMC in the Ferry building was so amazingly patient and helpful that all of my fears disappeared! Not only did they have exactly what I was looking for, but the counter guy actually talked me into buying less meat than I was planning on.  For me, this is a sign of a great butcher.  He knew how many servings I was looking for, and he didn't try to upsale me.  Which  is awesome, considering rack of lamb costs about $19.99 a pound and I ended up buying a half rack (for two people) for $11.70. 

So, next time I need something to cook that was once an animal, I'm heading to GGMC, no question!

Many thanks to everyone who helped yesterday, dinner came out amazing and the boy was incredibly happy!
author: Tiffany S.

description:
This is a review of the Meat store... they have a restaurant?????

This is not a dig, but I really wanted to give them 3.5***, but in the end, the pros outweighed the cons in this 5***** system.

First --- These guys know meat... I mean Meat. They are a purveyor to many, many restaurants. They sell quality meats. I would have no problem buying more Meat from them. There are no buts here. Just personal preference.

My professional obligation requires me to by Beef elsewhere. So I do. They sell other stuff. Pork is alright and I occasionally buy here when convenience dictates. Sausages are great in flavor (wide variety here)... poor in structure (tend to be loosely packed in casing and thus easily fall apart when cut into -- not what I'm looking for in a sausage I'm going to slice). Deli meats are average.

And then there is the bacon. I almost can't bring myself to mention it for fear some unwashed heathen will gain entry into the house of .... {gulp} Neuske's. I said it. OK... I don't like it with my breakfast, but is the BEST cooking bacon out there. A big 1/2' thick slab in the beans.... the collards.... cut thin to wrap around a scallop or pork tenderloin.... lardons for wilted Arugula with a warm bacon fat dressing.... {Angelic Choir Sings}

Oh yeah... and the people at the Meat counter are super cool too. 

So if you follow the trail of reviews I leave behind like that giant banana slug at Land's End... you'll see where I'm going for my meat, Why I go there instead of here, and...
author: Ryan F.

description: Chicken pot pie.  Purchased at 5pm. Tiny, salty, thick gooey - no recognizable vegetables inside.  Not good.
author: Chris H.

description: GG Meats specializes in natural and organic meats, and I have to say their cuts are some of the finest I've come across in my illustrious career as a meat -eater. Have ordered juicy pork chops, perfect steaks, you name it. This is a great butcher, no doubt about it!
author: Nish N.

description: they sold me some ground beef and ive had basically most of what they have and its all great, all fresh from coorado, or montatna and definately the only good place i get a single steak at thhat a big company doesnt mind a small order. awesoem people and better meat.
author: Jaime K.

description:
Helllooo hot pastrami sandwich!  If you like pastrami - and who doesn't - you'll be happy to eat one of these. 

It's not the sandwich counter meat-lettuce-tomato-cheese sandwich; it's pure - hot pastrami and spicy mustard on a fresh roll, that's it. 
The pastrami is kept hot in its own jus, and is sliced nice and thin. The large holes in the ciabatta-like roll is perfect for soaking up all the extra pastrami jus. I've gotten these more than a few times, and they are consistantly good. 

5 stars for the hot pastrami sandwich. When it's that good, you never really want to order or try anything else. Why risk the disappointment?
author: kristen b.

description: Never tried the prepared foods but they are easily one of my favorite butchers in the city. Their prosciutto, pork chops, steaks and ground beef are always impeccable. And the customer service is top notch, which is hard to find in SF.
author: Oly O.

description:
Finally, a REAL butcher in San Francisco! I thought I was going to have to move back to Chicago (yes, I've lived there, too). Real men cutting up real meat for the real foody. 

Me: Is your meat dry aged? 
Dean the meat man:  Absolutely, check this out (holds up gorgeous piece of meat)
Me: Can you cut it to order? 
Dean the meat man: Sure, what are you interested in? 
Me: A Porterhouse cut really thick. 
Dean MM: How thick do you want it? 
Me: At least two inches thick! 
Dean MM: No problem 
Dean MM proceeds to side of store to go into freezer room; comes back carrying side of cow. 

I love Dean! and after tonight so does my husband! Best dinner in SF since moving back!!! Nice thick steak, home made belgium fries, sauteed onions and mushrooms, home made brushetta with heirloom tomatos, and a bottle of Anderson Valley Golden Eye. 

Oh Yeah!
author: Razel F.

description:
My god!
Is that a hot pastrami sandwich? Gimmi! 7 bucks? Fine, ill pay, whatever it costs, smells good, seats around the corner. Munch munch, its good! Munch munch munch...Its very good! Gulp, all gone, homemade mustard, tasty. Outside, farmers market, what the hell is a smoked salmon stick? Sure ill take one. Fruits? Lemme "sample" all of them! Pure flavor. A perfect lunch? Possibly.
I'll be back for more!
author: Ross G.

description:
Mmm mmm  mmmeat.

You want it?  

They've got it.

A lot of it.
author: LeSLiE W.

description: Oh, meat love!  Pastrami, meatloaf, smoked  bbq pork, pulled chicken with mustard, sausageonastick.  Skip the dessicated veggies if poss.
author: Natasha S.

description:
i grabbed a bunch of sandwiches here to take a friend's place yesterday, not really expecting much and just hoping to capitalize on the shorter lines compared to boccalone... and was quite pleasantly surprised at how tasty they were! i think what makes it is the nice soft bread... i generally don't like hard, scratch-up-the-roof-of-your-mouth breads so this was totally my cup of tea!

the three sandwiches i got included:

- bbq pork: my favorite of the bunch; tasty and tender
- meatloaf: huge slab of meat but a tad on the cold side
- pulled chicken: nice with the honey mustard sauce

it's all about the meat here (makes sense right?)--no veggies or condiments except for some takeaway packets of ketchup, mustard and relish. i'd be interested in trying some of the pot pies which looked rustic and full of goodies. might have to stop by again soon...
author: Andrey C.

description:
Breakfast, lunch, and dinner, courtesy of the Ferry Building's Golden Gate Meat Co. Start your day with a step off the Larkspur or Sausalito Ferry, and stop off for a Sausage on a Stick for $2. Head back for lunch for some of the best barbeque beef sandwiches you'll have. Before you catch the ferry home, grab one of their $5 Rotisserie Chickens: it's small enough to fit in your bag and still be warm when you get home, and just perfect for two people to devour.

Of course, the quality of the meat is beyond parallel. Thanksgiving turkey orders are a dream here, too: ready and waiting for you. Their expanding selection of sides and helpful butcher staff make you question how you got so lucky to have the ferry, the building, and this great staff, all at amazingly inexpensive prices.

My kinda meat shop!
author: Joshua T.

description:
No I am not an expert on the perfect cut and couldn't tell you the difference between a cutlet and a fillet, but that doesn't matter because these folks can... and I like learning from the experts who have patience with idiot questions like mine.

Try throwing the ball to them:  just say you are having a BBQ and want a good variety to share.  Let them help you assemble a selection to make the perfect grill, and mix it up with some of their special (free) spice, salt & garlic meat rubs.

Throw in a few choice veggies (or not) from the exquisite Capay Farms behind you for shish-kebab, and you are golden.
author: Jim W.

description:
Excellent! Best rack of lamb and steak (so tender you could cut it with a fork) I've found in the city...these guys really know their stuff.
Try their beef jerkey. To die for.
author: Brianne K.

description:
This is THE place to go for all of your meat. Chris and Margo run an amazing shop. Everyone working here is friendly and helpful and they know all about what they're selling. I grew up in Kansas so I need a really good steak every week. This is the only place I trust to find me the perfect ribeye, porterhouse or NY. 

If you haven't checked it out you are missing one of the best shops  in the ferry building. LOVE YOU GUYS!
author: melissa n.

description: Just got the off-the-shelf no-big-deal new york strip.  Fantastic!  I mean, really really excellent cut of meat, and it wasnt even a "special" or "fresh today" or anything.  Reminds me of the butcher shops back home, and that is a *high* complement.
author: Andy G.

description: The BBQ pork sandwich was kind of bland.  I was hoping for a little more flavor/zest.
author: Mike S.

description:
Golden Gate Meat Company is awesome.  I would recommend this place to anyone that loves meat.  They know how to do it right but let me tell you about their jerky. 

Now I'm from the 'shire where smoked meat and dried meat is something we crave and admire.  GGMC is the only place in SF where I've found venison, elk, buffalo and other rare jerkies.  I bring this home every Christmas for my family and they are addicted.  Its really a special treat!!! If you are a fan of any of these rare jerkies, I would recommend calling first and placing an order to make sure they have it.  Venison sells out quickly!

I would also recommend this as the place to get snacks for any camping/ski/snow board trip.  Jerky on the slopes/mountains is heaven on earth.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Can't rate the butcher, cuz  I haven't tried it.  But the little sandwich shop on the promenade... oh dear.  So I got the pulled pork.  At first, you see the half-roll and think, gee, that looks kinda small for $6.  Then you see them fill it to about double its previous size with luscious, tender, juicy, porky goodness.  This ain't pork for the faint of heart - not judging by the quantity of luscious grease that dripped out while I was munching - and especially considering that there's nothing on that sandwich but bread, pork, and some tasty, tangy, almost fruity BBQ sauce.
This is not a healthy sandwich.  In fact, it doesn't belong in the same room, perhaps not even the same building as the word healthy.  But DAMN was it good.
author: Don H.

description:
I'll keep this short and sweet: great meat.  not cheap mind you, but you get what you pay for.  best fillets I've ever purchased -- easily shaming pricier wagyu and kobe I've bought elsewhere.

extra points for being a *real* butcher shop too: I called and asked if they could provide me with 12 lbs. of veal bones (I do my own stocks) -- no problem.  they had them wrapped and set aside for me to pick up by name later.  bravo.  they were three-bucks a pound (ouch), but had a hell of a lot of meat left on them at that price... as it should be.

oh -- and any butcher that supplies mythbusters with some of their gore is okay in my book :-P
author: Mark B.

description:
The pulled pork sandwich is really good
Has a spicy and sweet sauce... 
but their cole slaw has a vinegar based dressing,
not the traditional sweet mayo. minus one star for that.

The meat loaf sandwich is also very good.
I get the gravy on the side.

Also, even on Saturdays, GGMC's queue is not at all long.
Seating in the market side off of the main hall of the building.
author: Geordie E.

description: I love their chorizo sausage here. It's the best in the city. It's not the Mexican or Salvadorian style, but the Spanish style chorizo, which is pretty much impossible to find anywhere else. The lady behind the counter told me the first time I bought it that I will be back and she was right. Now any time I am cooking a Spanish dish that requirers chorizo, or want to have just a snack of chorizo in a flambéed brandy sauce, this is there I shop!
author: Yelena K.

description:
Why 3 stars you may ask yourself -- because it seems as though EVERYONE gave it at least 4... well, almost. 

First off, I think the people who work here, super nice, friendly and even funny!  

BUT

None of my co-workers today (maybe one) had a settled stomach after our meal. And I am not sure how I can explain this.  My meatloaf COMBO, as my friend Mark liked to call it CARGO plate was decent. The veggies, decent. I think the carrots, could be a LITTLE more cooked and the celery a little less... but that's okay.  Veggies are a hard type of food to please everyone with - in term so texture and how well done they become after they get tossed in the cooker. 

My meatloaf - looked kind of odd. Some parts were TOO well done, others not enough and then there was something just not right.  

I feel like the Cookie Monster, with a grumbling stomach through the 2nd half of the work day - at my cube, wondering... what's going on down in that rumbly tumbly?! 

I may go back, but I think I would prep my stomach first... 

On a side note, it's a cute place to go to grab food for a date! Outside. On the benches. In the sun.  Oh wait, the sun isn't often out behind the clouds in the City. Still - cute idea.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Golden Gate Meat Company has the best pastrami on the west coast, by a huge margin.  It's juicy and smoky and tender, and for $6 they pile it high on some bread with a little mustard.  That's all it needs.  Try the lemonade too, it's got some vanilla in it, kind of strange but pretty good.

Also, check the blackboard when you get there -- if one of the specials is their meatball sub or their Italian sausage sub, try it.  You won't regret it.
author: Marco C.

description:
Cheapest fulfilling meal you can get at the Ferry Building. How can you go wrong with a half roasted chicken and roasted vegetables for 6 bucks? That's a freaking steal!! (FYI, I saw on the chalkboard something about raising prices in August?)

There was a bunch of other tantalizing goodies too like the pot pies, pizza, sausage sticks, and bbq meats. I MUST TRY THEM ALL! RAWR! I WILL BE BACK!

And word of caution, if you sit infront of their meat counter while eating, you'll only get more hungry! BEWARE!
author: Lester L.

description:
The location and service were nice, but the food is definitely not something to call home about.

I shared a bbq pork sandwich and 1/2 chicken combo plate with a friend. 

The sandwich bun was good and the general flavor was spot on (not too sweet or overpowering), but the pork was on the dry side and did not taste especially fresh. 

The highlight of the chicken combo was the potatoes, which were deliciously spiced and just the right texture. The dark meat on the chicken was decent - better than chain rotisseries, but the white meat was dry. You could probably find something similar at an above average American buffet.

The total came out to 14 (7 per item) and the food was filling enough, but there was definitely no wow factor as we had expected based on reviews.  A chicken bake from costco would pleasure my stomach lining a little more. Decent cafeteria-fare food with above-average service and a nice view of treasure island as you eat.
author: Eric H.

description: Hot pastrami sandwich= pastrami, bread, deli mustard. Upon seeing the sandwich, I thought I would miss additional toppings such as cheese and sauerkraut. I soon realized, however, that when the pastrami is that good, it doesn't need any embellishments that might detract from the flavor of the meat. I did think it was quite a lot of bread for the sandwich, although the bread was very good. The longer I ate my sandwich the longer the meat juice had to soak into the bun, reducing the bread's resistance to to being chewed. This sandwich was solid. I'd eat here again anytime (as long as I can follow the meal with a three hour workout).
author: m t.

description:
Just about the best butcher this side of the Mississippi.  Ok, ok - that may be an overstatement but this place is the real deal.  

Their meats don't come cheap, but man -- they are fresh.  The staff are friendly and patient (it took me 10 minutes to make a decision of what cut to buy the last time I was there).

Bryan's on California is a good butcher too but I think GGMC beats it hands down.  This place is cleaner and the people nicer.
author: Clarice V.

description:
This review is for the butcher.  They have two or three faaantastic sandwiches for lunch.  In order of preference: 1) The Meatloaf 2) Pastrami 3) Pulled Pork.

Fair warning, please allow 2 to 3 hours to sleep immediately following your meal.  And you will probably end up with a little bbq sauce on your shirt.  But those are small prices to pay.
author: Michael N.

description:
So sick to death of the rubbish that supermarkets palm off at meat I was overjoyed to discover a fantastic, full service butcher in the heart of the Ferry Building.

Chris and his team at Golden Gate Meats is a phenomenal butcher without hideous pricing.  Their product is excellent at every level and it is the only place I have ever seen proper English style back bacon at which makes wonderful bacon sandwiches.

In addition they will source and butcher any type of meat to your exact specification.  I've had everything from pork bellies and loin roasts with the skin on for crackling to black pudding from them and I've never found them unable to deliver on a request.

A special mention must go to their organic dry aged beef.  Now this *is* expensive but good lord it is worth it.  I bought a massive New York Strip steak roast from them for a big family dinner and it yielded the most delicious, buttery flesh.

I haven't had cause to try their rubs or butters as I tend to make them at home but I have no reason to doubt they will be anything less than delicious.
author: Tony S.

description:
I read the review and was excited about trying the place. Massive disclaimer here: I am not a huge fan of sandwiches in general. 

I was impressed that you could actually get a sandwich here for $6 considering its in the Ferry Building and trying to get a meal here for less then $10 is like trying to buy an apartment in San Francisco for $100K. Ok, that may not be a useful analogy but I do appreciate the sub-$10 meal here. The italian sausage sandwich was very good. Would have been even better if they heated the bread or offered some more choices on the type of bread. Overall, a solid place and a much welcome alternative to the pricier establishments in the Ferry Building.
author: Abhi S.

description: Great beef pot pie: caramelized (not burnt!) crust and onion filling.  Chicken pot pie is also available.  Okay macaroni and cheese.  Very good $2 sausages on a stick.  I wish there was more variety than mild or spicy.
author: Ai M.

description: WEDNESDAY Skirt Steak Sammich Day ROCKS!!! MMM MMM Good i highly suggest it... Make sure save some for me.........
author: Felisha Y.

description:
One of the few great breakfast sandwiches I have had on the west coast... Personal tip: ask for one with spicy sausage and you will get a fresh made spicy, gooey, warm breakfast sandwich that seems to melt in your mouth (the bacon ones seem to be made en masse and wait in the warm case until purchase).

Lunch: the half chicken with veggies and potatoes is quite yummy and a steal from typical ferry building prices at only $6.
author: Morgen N.

description: I love this place for coppa, elk jerky, and roast beef. I just walk over there, order a 1/4# of whatever comes to mind, and that's my lunch.
author: Johnson H.

description:
Excellent butcher. You probably know this already.

What you may NOT know is that they can special order  items such as quail or duck eggs within a day, and  their veal stock is excellent.
author: Pamela B.

description:
Friendly, knowledgeable people wrapping up deelish local and sustainably grown meat for my cooking pleasure.  Slicing, grinding, trimming, whatever I want...which is a given for a butcher shop but rare, and a pleasure to find, here in good ol' SF.  And suggestive about all the right things (corn beef hash anyone?), damn!

And it's an added bonus that the butcher I get my meat from supplies the Mythbusters with their piggy side-kicks.
author: Emma L.

description:
Golden Gate Meat Company mainly sells beef and meats of that sort, so when we ordered turkey, we were not expecting much...

WOW, we were surprised...this was some of the best sliced turkey I had ever eaten!

I will definitely go back, when I want to pick up some meat...not guys...BEEF or Turkey!!!!!
author: Elaine S.

description:
another Friday visit to the ferry buildling to try yet another food booth...after some picking and choosing about what to eat today, WLB and I settled on trying out the BBQ at Golden Gate Meat Company.  ironically, neither of us actually got BBQ.

my order - 1/2 of a roisissore chicken + mac-n-cheese side: the chicken was good - moist and sufficiently roitissoried but not amazing; the mac-n-cheese on the other hand was sadly disappointing as it was bland, not cheesy enough, and all in all, forgettable at best. if given the choice again I would've opted for the grilled veggies as my side. still for a lot of food and only $7, it was a reasonable price.

WLB's order - meatball/sausage/saucey sandwich: he didn't talk much, so I'll assume it was a-ok...plus, we got the visual approval from a passer-by who remarked, "WOW, that's SOME sandwich!" when WLB pulled open the foil encassing the said sandwich.

have no frame of reference as for the uncooked meats at the GG Meat Company if i go back again I think next time I'll stick to the BBQ sandwiches.
author: Grace O.

description:
Hubby's Review:

Great meat, duh!  Very decent selection of food.  Reminiscent of an old butcher's store.  I'm a carnivore so I can't ever complain about a meat store!
author: Mr. and Mrs. L.

description:
I recently bought a pound of venison here for the V-Day's dinner I was cooking. Couldn't believe they actually stock it... Fucking amazing! I seriously have never had better venison in my life, restaurants included. 

If you need any type of good meat go here. I promise you won't be let down.
author: Mike A.

description:
this review is ONLY FOR THE HOT PASTRAMI SANDWICH!

golden gate meat co. has THE BEST hot pastrami sandwich in the city!

i make it a point to try any restaurant's hot pastrami if i see it on a menu, but never thought i'd find SF's winner at a meat market stand.

throw ton's of their HOMEMADE mustard on the perfect roll for a hot pastrami sandwich, piles of that greasy goodness pastrami, and you're good.  take that baby out to the pier on a sunny day and enjoy the view of the ferry building and the bay bridge.
author: dan a.

description: This is based on a pot pie and pizza. Pot pie's crust was nice and flaky but the inside was just dry and no sauce and salty and only filled up half of the already small ass pie. Gosh, i wish they told me it sucked before i bought it so that at least i could've had my expectations set and lowered before biting into the damn thing. The pizza had bacon and mushroom on it. it looked good on display but when i bit into it, it was hard and dry so it all crumbled apart after that first bite. I have a yucky feeling that it was yesterday's pizza just reheated. I went back to tell them about it. The 2 girls at the counter laughed and apologized but no money back or replacement pieces. That  just screams "Eek! Methinks not" all over it for me.
author: Nick V.

description:
I had the meatloaf with potatoes and vegetables meal and it wasn't very good. The meatloaf was too dry and salty, and still flavorless. It had a very dark black color to it, so it wasn't attractive looking. I'm used to meatloaf that had ketchup/bbq sauce on top and that was missing. Also the sauce wasn't good either, it was equally flavorless. 
the vegetables with potatoes were alright, nothing special. i could've made better at home really. But for 6 dollars you can't expect very much.
I would say even Boston Market has better meatloaf than they do. but they are much smaller portioned and stingy with the sides too. much more expensive also.
author: Darby W.

description:
So convenient, right near the office.  The soup is always good, and at $2.50 for a small one, it's about the best deal in the Ferry Building.  Always stop next door at Acme to pick up a roll for 70 cents, find a bench outside.  Very nice.  The red beans and rice soup is a real standout, as is the beef barley.

I had the pastrami today (minor hangover) - just what the doctor ordered!  Tasty-pooh.  I'm not an ex-NewYorker, so I cannot possibly compare it with "The Real Thang" (whatever that means), but it was memorably good.  

The help is very nice and, considering the mix of touristas and financial district types they deal with, they maintain their good, if not jaded, humor.
author: Curtdude T.

description:
This is my first review on yelp, and unfortunately it is a negative one.

We ordered a 22lb organic turkey from golden gate meat company on November 4th. When I arrived today to pick it up, they said that they did not have an organic turkey for us and that despite having our phone number they did not call in advance to tell us they did not have the turkey. My ferry was coming, and options were short as Thanksgiving is tomorrow and we start cooking the bird early, so I went with the next turkey option which I learned tonight is much less expensive, for the same exact turkey at another grocery store.

Also, the stuffing and gravy were significantly overpriced.
author: Dan R.

description: BBQ pulled pork sandwich....Generous portion of pork piled in a hefty roll. It's messy and filling, but not in the good for the soul kind of way. I thought it was sweet, not particularly tender, and lacking that intensity of flavor that you expect from slow cooked pork. I would however go back to try the sausages and butcher shop.
author: Faye P.

description: I've been here for a sandwich at lunch on a number of occasions.  The meats are good, but not great.  Flavorful, but can be a bit dry.  Service at the counter is not good, though.  I think you're better off grabbing something from the Farmer's Market or from Taylor's (Gott's) and enjoying the view of the Bay.
author: Gabe C.

description: Wanted a pulled chicken sandwich.  Settled for pulled beef on account of lack of chickens.  Combined with barley salad a pretty hearty meal.  Pretty pricy - 8ish for bread and BBQ meat 2.5ish for the side.  Tangy BBQ sauce, and the beef was juicy.  Overall a great lunch, but at a price.
author: Michael C.

description:
I used to come in here to grab cold cuts as snacks when I lived in Marin and took the ferry home, the turkey literally tastes like Thanksgiving turkey, I mean like it had the gravy and all and the pastrami is also incredible tastes better than most bacons.

I come in here every now and then to grab all types of meat, but a few days ago I came in and tried the duck/pork/port/ fig sausage which is hands down the best sausage I have ever had in my life, topping the flavor of many steaks I have had at very good restaurants. The guys at Prather Meats across the way from them have some pretty incredible sausage as well, but this was out of this world good. Too bad it is only seasonal.

They also sell a great garlic parsley butter there that makes an incredible garlic bread or if you are feeling like being a real fat boy to throw on a steak right before you take it off the grill.
author: Erich G.

description: The only reason to go to a butcher shop is for good customer service.  The staff here is very knowledgeable and they will hook up a special cut when you want an odd weight like 2.5 lbs and such. The prices are comparable to Whole Foods and Prather Ranch.
author: Roger H.

description: We've purchases the Rotisserie chicken a few times as well as other items and they've all been OK. It honestly is just OK. I would never make a special trip to buy something there but I would for other places in the building. It's just good to have something different every once in a while.
author: Diane M.

description: Grab a bite at the hot prepped foods counter and head out to the outside deck. Yes, you'll battle Hitchcock-esque birds and eat on a park bench, but the killer views are worth it. Service was inches away from rude, but the food was good for take-out.
author: Janet D.

description:
one of the reasons im glad i moved to soma. 

*tear* ....

of joy,

maybe soju. 

i really cant say more than whats been said. great lunches. great meat selection... wait is that a slab of elk prime rib? bone in? no doubt. 

local, small business, generations deep, doing what they know best. 

that is all
author: Euge L.

description: Buffalo -- Strip steaks, rib eye, ground or other cuts ... delicious. Amazing taste, different then beef, but subtly so. My connection at GGMC brought me a pile of Buffalo rib eyes... and they are amazing.  My guy at GGMC kind of apologized, and I'm thinking -- are you kidding? This is Great! Buffalo. You gotta try it. Buffalo meat is lower in fat, lower in cholestrol, and higher in the meaty nutrients that are good for us. Plus, buffalo can't live on the horrible corn-diets that are forced on cows, which means the animals themselves are healthier overall and don't require all the antibiotics. I've have buffalo meat from other sources, but serious, GGMC has the best tasting, most beautiful buffalo steaks I've ever had.
author: Heather W.

description: Meatloaf Sandwich. Sourdough Roll. Mushroom Gravy. Why are you still reading this!
author: Ryan G.

description: $7 for half a chicken w/ potatoes or veggies.  Great for lunch when working in FiDi.  They are super nice - if the food isn't ready and you offer to wait, they invite you to go sit down and bring the food to you, with a cookie since you went to the trouble of waiting.
author: Green Y.

description: I  recently bought 1 pound ground beef. I asked them if this is grass fed and  fresh, they say yes. Going home,  I opened it and found some portions were very gray and parsley (!) in the meat.  Had never seen vegetable in ground meat in entire my life. I was not comfortable and will never buy at this meat shop.  Usually I buy at Wholefood Market, their one is never gray meat and with something like  parsley in side. I don't trust Golden Gate Meat Company.
author: AI T.

description: It's a bit pricey but this is my favorite butcher in the city.  They are very accommodating and the cuts are always fresh.  Made my first prime rib with their meat and it was delicious, I'd like to think it was my awesome cooking skills but I have a feeling nobody could have messed up the piece of meat I bought.  Also love the fact that they carry bone marrow.
author: Jen C.

description: I'm a little surprised... ok I won't lie, EXTREMELY surprised no one's mentioned the chili here.  I may have scared off the poor British tourists next to me eating it because not only did I say "omg omg, mmm mmm" after every single bite, my eyes rolled to the back of my head too many times to count.  I have had many bowls of chili in my day, but this place seriously brought tears to my eyes.  It was the perfect way to drown my sorrows.  They don't fucking mess around.  Try the chili.  Or inhale it, as I did.  You won't be sorry.
author: Emily C.

description: OK: the wild boar and the venison sausages,  as well as their selection of cured Italian meats makes up for my last experience.
author: N B.

description: Every time I come here the staff are so friendly and helpful and fun! The steaks we've bought here have been consistently good, though the prices are a bit hard to handle at times. Overall, I'd say it's worth it though!
author: Sarcastic T.

description: I bought a beef tenderloin from here to try to duplicate a recipe Bobby Flay made on Iron Chef. Scary prospect but it turned out awesome! I would love to say its my master chef abilities in the kitchen, but having a great cut of meat can make or break this sort of crazy cooking experimentation. It was an $80 piece of meat, and I have to say, you get what you pay for. They will do any cut of meat you want, as any good butcher shop should, and they are super friendly and knowledgeable. Not for the budget conscious...but, as I mentioned before, you get what you pay for, and their meats are top notch.
author: Drue C.

description: There aren't many stores open before 8am at the Ferry Building, which is why this place is great. Not only do they have delicious sausage on a stick (hot or mild, $2), but three choices of breakfast sandwiches (sausage, egg, applewood bacon, etc) each for $5. Not a bad deal for a quick bite in the morning. Of course this place has great meats during the day as well, I just appreciate that they cater to the morning crowd as well...
author: Nicolas H.

description: Pretty delicious mild Italian sausage (which went nicely with the morels in the pasta dish we made Sunday night).  Nice looking meat counter.
author: Laurel B.

description:
This is really just a review of the breakfast sandwich from the Golden Gate Meat Company.

One of my guilty pleasure I indulge in on most of my trips to SF is to walk to the Ferry Marketplace building on a weekend morning, grab a coffee from Peet's and a breakfast sandwich from the Golden Gate Meat Company. I sit by the water, enjoying the weather, wondering why I have to return to the frozen tundra that is Boston in winter.

There are plenty of folks making breakfast sandwiched but somehow GG hit the jackpot with their recipe. The egg is perfectly yummy and runny, not the typical yellow, overcooked rubbery junk many places produce in the name of "food safety" these days. The meat and the bun somehow all work together and it just melts into a delicious whole right in your mouth.
author: Gunnar E.

description: I had the spicy Italian on a stick. Nice quick bite for $2. Next time I'm in this area I want to indulge in some of their deli selections and head to the park for a picnic. This is the 1st place that I've been where it looks like they take their meat aging seriously. The cuts looked beautiful. so 2ndly, If I had the $$$ to throw down I would've gotten a strip or porterhouse. I will be back someday, I promise!
author: Niki P.

description:
I think that America needs to take a step back in time to an era when everyone got their chops and loins  from a neighborhood butcher.  Y'know, the kind that'll save a lamb legbone as a treat for your dog.  Now that most of America gets prepackaged meat, Golden Gate is a rarity ensconced in the gourmet shrine that is the Ferry Building.  Golden Gate has quality meat, and like any good butcher, you can call ahead for unusual requests for non-standard cuts or variety meats.  You can ask them to French a crown roast and they won't look at you like you're a perv.

However, Golden Gate leaves me wanting because sometimes, the people who work there can be a total stick in the mud (or something else that rhymes with "stick").  Now, I would never malign a purveyor of meats without good reason.  And I'm sure they have to deal with a lot of douchebags who think they're Emeril or Thomas Keller due to the Ferry Building locale, but sometimes, I ask a simple question and get stonewalled with attitude.  Is it that stupid to ask what the difference between two pastramis if there is a tag that says "Golden Gate natural pastrami brisket" and one that says "David's pastrami"?  Well, excuuuuse me if I don't know that the two separate tags are for the same hunk of meat!  And it's not even the kind of goodhearted attitude I appreciate, like the dudes at Genova Deli in Oakland.  The grumpy old guys there would mock-groan when I ask them to carve out the bread a little for my meatball sandwich, but they do it and give me a "Weeelll, I'm only doing this special for you" smirk.  They know how to charm, and it makes their food taste extra good.

I guess what I hope for every time at Golden Gate, besides thick cut veal chops or beautiful steaks, is a special little interaction you get when you buy from someone who gives a damn.  What can I say, butcher shops make me sentimental about the way things used to be in this world.  Golden Gate gives a damn about meat, but sometimes I get treated like I'm a piece of meat, chopped liver to be precise.  And that, my friends, makes me a little sad, like when I think about carbon monoxied-treated prepackaged meat.
author: maiko h.

description: They have andouille sausage for gumbo, as well as interesting meat, such as venison chops. I liked their homemade wine cured salami.
author: Vena V.

description: Oh my goodness, this place makes the best hot pastrami sandwich I've ever had!  Nice thick hot pastrami and their home made dijon mustard.  *drools*  I went around 11:30am during the week for lunch and there was no line.  Kinda sad that my friend from SoCal who has never been to SF told me to go here.  :\
author: Casey F.

description: Went here specifically to purchase a specific meat product on March 18.  Got it home to find the SELL BY DATE WAS FEB 12.  REALLY???  Will never eat or shop here again.
author: Jade D.

description: Great pot pies and awesome bbq pork sandwich!
author: Derrick L.

description:
Update: MARCH 08 - THIS IS MY NEW FAVORITE PLACE- THEY HAVE GUANCIALE WHICH IS TOTALLY INSANE; THE BEST INFGREDIENTS IF YOU'RE GOING TO HAVE A HANDMADE PIZZA PARTY. It's really a MEAT LOVER'S HEAVEN. GGM has got some friendly folks behind the counter and in the pre-bbq season they're pushing a free coating of their dry rub which they did on my USDA prime hanger steak yesterday which cooked up on my indoor grill pan LIKE A DREAM. Now, with seating, you can get something from the takeout window (pot pie, pizza, real steamed pastrami) and have a seat and look at the MEAT!

FERRY PLAZA FRUGAL: (when you buy food you also earn the right to sit in the GGM seating area inside the ferry plaza!)
Ok, so I'm not cheating on my Prather Ranch Boys because technically, I've never purchased any raw meat here, just the deli/hot counter for 
- flakey, rich chicken pot pies for about $6
- sicilian pizza slice with crazy meat, meat, meat just enough sauce and cheese on artizan crust a steal for $3 a slice
- Mac-n-chz-- not so much, scary, chalky, seriously lacking cheese flavour why so disappointing.  
They also have Sausage on a stick, not my kind of viz aesthetic.  And, breakfast sandwiches with various yummy meats...
But in my personal opinion the egg in a breakfast sandwich needs to be scrambled rather than soft-fried because runny yolk defeats the purpose of breakfast sandwich convenience and I don't eat raw yolk people, and I'm one of the few people who live in SF (originally from the opp coast) who will eat a greasy breakfast sandwich filled with meat, egg and cheese as long as the eggs are scrambled.

Good place to go when you're saving a buck or two at the Ferry Plaza and can't just survive on CC cheese and Acme rolls.
author: E L.

description: When I got of the bus in the FIDI this morning I smelled bbq beef. I know, strange smell for 8:00 am downtown. I proceed to my desk where I thought about the Meat Company's BBQ beef sandi all morning long. I convinced a coworker to walk to the ferry building with me. I got the BBQ beef sandwich, he had 1/2 a chicken. It was amazing as always. It cost $6, but when you consider its about a pound of meet and it is at the ferry building , that seems pretty reasonable.
author: Kelly P.

description: Got 2.5lbs of a pork loin here today while at the market- took it home and did it up Spanish style with a nice spice rub and roasted it for about 1.25 hrs. Was awesome, tender and totall juicy even though I am realizing now that I forgot to sear it first like I learned in my cooking class. (This was one of the 2 dishes I actually cooked in an all-day class...see my Tante Marie review.) If you're interested in the recipe - and I say that loosely- meaning if you want to know some basic ingredients I used to prepare it- write me and I'm happy to share. The whole family enjoyed it. Yum. Will definitely buy from them again!
author: Diane S.

description: GG Meats is the best butcher I've found in SF.  The guys behind the counter are very helpful, and are all actually butchers (as opposed to the goobers behind the meat counter at, say, Whole Foods in SOMA).  I've gotten a bunch of different things at GG Meats, but the standouts are the frenched (lollipopped) veal chops and the foie gras.
author: Jeff S.

description: BBQ BEEF SANDIWCH HERE IS AWESOME and only 6 bucks.  Also teh Pastrami Melt Sando for 7 bucks.  With the ridiculously overpriced places in the Ferry Building this is by far the best deal and meal in this building.  Such a good sando, please try it out.
author: Harry E.

description:
Read about the pastrami and just had to give it a try.
I was disappointed.  It has flavor (better flavor than that from M & L Market), but the texture was not what I expected pastrami to have.  It's not exactly like leather, but kind of similar--rough, not really tough but tough enough to not be a pleasure to eat.  It was like eating dried brisket slices that I had from Memphis Minnie's, except with some jus.  They keep their hot pastrami with jus in a container in the display case; I find this foreign because The Jew and the Gentile (now closed) always sliced the hot pastrami in front of me from a large slab.  I asked the counter girl what kind of bread they have, and she said all they use is the Acme French roll.  I asked whether it was tough (I wear braces), and she said no.  She lied.
(By the way, you buy the hot lunch from the counter in the main walk in the Ferry Building, just outside and around the corner from the main butcher shop.)

8/3/2007 update:
Went back to give their chicken pot pie a try.  It was mildly disappointing, but passable.  It's not salty, and the crust is good.  But it lacks flavor.  It needs more celery and pepper and spices (like tarragon) and chicken.  It needs a bit more chicken meat.  (They charge $6 for a pie for chrissake!)  Take a lesson from Bakesale Betty in Oakland (who once made pot pies in the single sizes). Now that's a lesson that's worth the money.

I'm now wondering whether I should try the beef pot pie.
author: Joe D.

description:
This place is amazing. 

(1) Best bagels I've found in the financial district. Forget about Noah's bread patties. These are crispy-on-the-outside, chewy-on-the-inside for-real boiled bagels. 

(2) Generous portions and affordable prices. While I appreciate that the Ferry Building is home to many ethical/sustainable/organic food sellers, the Golden Gate Meat Co. is one of the few places (in the ferry building) that doesn't equate that ethical stance with exorbitant prices. Pork sandwiches are piled so high, you could eat it for two meals. I can't remember the last time I used all the cream cheese they dole out for bagels. The best: For $5, I can get a large portion of delicious soup and a roll from Acme next door. 

(3) The lunch line trauma of the ferry building is non-existent! Walk up, order, get your food, walk away. YES!
author: Celeste L.

description: Best pastrami I have ever had. Better than Katz in New York. Amazing chilling will be eating here once a week. Found this gem and loved staff, food and prices!
author: Mia M.

description:
I will never buy meat from anywhere else.  I used to buy meat at Whole Foods or Draegers, but this place puts them to shame.  They have more cuts of a Buffalo than most grocery stores have of beef.  If you are the type of person that buys meat at Costco, freezes it, thaws it out a month later in the microwave and bbq's it to a nice medium-well temp, then don't waste your money at this place.  But if you can appreciate the difference between a mediocre cut of meat and an exceptional, juicy, prime cut, then this is where you want to go.  

The butchers here know everything about meat and how to prepare it - it's like buying drugs.  They even hold a weekly support group for addicts to the $35/lb kobe sirloin.  And when they ask you if you want the dry rub, the answer is yes.  Get it on the side if you are unsure, but it's good to let it soak in for awhile too.  They won't ask you if the cut is too good (like the kobe) so don't worry.

It's just all about the variety and quality.  You can't buy a bad steak here.
author: Bob B.

description: We have been regular customers of Golden Gate Meats for several years. The service is great - fast and very friendly - all the staff know me by first name. The quality of their meat is the best in SF by a long stretch. I just had an organic filet last night - so flavorful, tender and fresh - no need for any seasoning. They also have the most amazing organic rolled turkey breasts - I smoke on on the grill every week and toss it in salads. They make different rolled meat specials daily - my favorite is pounded chicken breast stuffed with mozzerela and proscuitto.
author: Joe M.

description: The meat delicatessen looks superb. However, I'm only a consumer of their cooked meat lunch menu. The to-go selection doesn't look as appetizing yet I chose a turkey pot pie for that afternoon lunch. To my surprise, it was good...but i think it would have tasted 3x better if it was served right out of the oven. Must try - SAUASAGE-ON-A-STICK
author: Oanh N.

description: Yes, their selection of meat are exquisite...but its the pastrami I dream about!
author: Christena R.

description: For a lunch to cure those who have the major hungers, three words: HOT PASTRAMI SANDWICH!!!!!!!!
author: Michelle G.

description: Yes, yes, the fare is pricey, but we did get an awesome rack of lamb crown roast for Christmas eve. This time, the fat was shaved off, so it was clearly more meat than fat (not so from another famed butcher on the other side of town). Our ex-caterer friend raves about this place, and given that she has exquisite taste, we buy with assurance (or did I mean abandon?).
author: Leah B.

description: The Hot Pastrami Sandwich with extra mustard will set you free!
author: Ed B.

description: I ate the Bufallo Blue Cheese Chicken Sandwich there yesterday. Let me break it down. Breaded chicken wings, grilled peppers and onions on a Francesi roll with Blue Cheese dressing. Boo YAHH!!!!!!! Its owned and operated by some friends of mine from Petaluma. Those P Town boys know how to procure some good meats.
author: Sam S.

description: Golden Gate was great. I've been here twice now and have tried the BBQ beef and breaded chicken (special) sandwiches.  The BBQ beef was a 5 and the chicken sandwich was a 4.  I definitely recommend checking this place out.
author: J S.

description: I haven't tried their butcher shop quite yet but have taken advantage of the hot station in the concourse. While most of the terminal offerings are not in the "inexpensive" category, I'd suggest a meal of two italian sausages on a stick (mild or hot) and a side of the roasted veggies. Delicious! Limited seating inside the shop, so if weather is great head outside to the benches.
author: Anthony F.

description: I stopped by here the other day for lunch mainly because the price was more reasonable than most other shops in the building. We got two bbq sandwiches - one beef and one pork. It was $12 ($6 each) and they were both delicious! Great steal in the ferry building!
author: Barney M.

description: Being jewish, and having lived on the East Coast for a few years, I know a little something about Pastrami. And I can whole-heartedly say that Pastrami Sandwich at GG Meats in the Ferry Building kicks serious ass. Get it with a root beer or Dr. Brown's, and it's pretty much like pairing a 1982 Chateaux Margaux with Foie Gras. Only greasier - don't forget the napkins.
author: Jonas J.

description: If you go to the "lunch counter" where they sell the sandwiches, beware, it's only lunch. You can't get a bitchin pastrami sandwich after 6 pm. The other part, which I believe is more of the butcher shop/grocery store stays open a little later.
author: Susannah R.

description:
I realize that this place probably does more business selling actual meat than sandwiches but alas, their location in the Ferry Building is unbeatable and the warm, carved meat in the window is hard to pass up. We got suckered into a couple of sandwiches. I was torn between the hot pastrami and their signature pulled roast chicken sandwich. We decided to get both and share. My bad for misinterpreting the menu. It said, "Pulled roast chicken sandwich with our own honey mustard" Ok, sounds harmless enough right? I love me some mustard. Man, I don't know if there was more mustard or more bread. The chicken was absolutely doused in mustard. And we're not talking just spread on, it was literally tossed through every single piece of pulled chicken. Now I love mustard, but not this much. The pastrami was good too...nothing to write home about. It was hot, that was for sure but a little fatty. Luckily, the mustard wasn't too heavy on that one. 

Next time, I might ask for the chicken sandwich, hold the mustard.....please!
author: Josephine H.

description: Finally got around to ordering the pastrami sandwich for lunch today. Never liked the looks of it soaking in all thsoe juices, but turned out to be superbly delicious. They use David's pastrami which is one probably the best stuff not coming out of NYC. Smokey, tender, juicy...
author: Brian J.

description: This place has to be the tastiest carnivore stop in the neighborhood. The bbq beef and pork sandwiches are finger lickin awesome. Have a side of the sesame seed cole slaw, with a freshly squeezed lemonade....You can take your fixin's out to the water and watch all the commuter boats come in with a smashing view of the bay too....Damn seagulls, come back with my bread...! Enjoy
author: Sven S.

description: While I was sleeping that night after eating the pulled pork sandwich for lunch I experienced "dry mouth" I attribute to MSG .  Not good.
author: Robert C.

description: The only place so far that Sharon and I have visited more than once. It doesn't have much of a menu, but there are daily specials that change regularly and the food is decent priced for being in the ferry building. The first time we went i had the meat loaf, which was excellent and a side of vegetables that were decent and some oily potatoes. Sharon had a hot dog...normal. The second time we split the special chicken enchilada casserole, which was delicious.
author: Matt H.

description: Yummer nummer nummers. Lovely meat and excellent Portuguese chorizo. I've never been disappointed with their offerings. Highly recommended. Oh, and nice lunch offerings, too.
author: Mark W.

description:
Golden Gate Meat Company is one of the very few sources for Prime grade beef in the area.  Their products are absolutely excellent and their service is even better.  You might pay a slight premium over chain supermarkets, but Golden Gate's prices are better than any of the 
"high-end" markets in the city or Marin that I've been to.  These guys (and gals) are great!  Best in the city!
author: J H.

description: I will join the chorus of Golden Gate Meat praisers. I've been going to them 2x a week or so since they opened in the Ferry Building.  Everyone who works there is friendly, knowledgeable and when you're not sure what you want, patient. The NY Organic steak is to die for, especially with the dry rub (you MUST get the dry rub!) A little expensive, but great for an exceptional piece of meat (or chicken, bacon, or whatever other meat you're looking for).  This place has spoiled me...I can never go back to eating supermarket meat again.
author: Madhavi K.

description: Get the hot pastrami from the lunch counter. Best I've had in my life. Even better than the overpriced stuff on the Lower East Side (sorry but it's true). And they used fresh bread from the bakery next store. Can't beat that! Shame is that only topping available is mustard which is good but I had to go to Max's to buy pickles. What the fuck is up with serving the best pastrami on earth with no pickles? Sounds like my personal hell. Next time I'll brind my homemade pickles with me. It's actually really hard to find good pickles around here. Don't know why Bay Area is crap for delis in general. I mean jeez it's too the point where I think Lee's is good because it's cheap, consistent, and efficient.
author: Todd H.

description: Finally a great establishment to get meat.  I would put 2 to 3 dollar signs next to it though, but you get what you pay for, no mystery to it.
author: Damien J.

description: While I am surprised at dismayed by the scarcity of quality butchers in San Francisco, Golden Gate Meat Company eases the pain.  The meats are generally of excellent quality and the selection is wide -- offering both standard and less common meats (i.e., quail) and cuts (i.e., true hangar steaks).  Most of the countermen are true butchers -- they know their stuff and are happy to cut to order.  One star off, however, for the one or two occassions that I was served by someone less knowledgable.  Bonus: the barbecue and other hot sandwiches available for carry out are delicious and a great value when you need a bellful of beef in a hurry.
author: Charlie Z.

description: this meat market is where i can find excellent cuts of meat. cured meats, wild game, jerkys, and more. this is one of the couple of places in the city i get my fresh chorizo. what i get in the mission always seems to be chorizo with all the byproducts. you know, assholes, lips, salivary glands, and lympnodes. not my style sorry to say. i like to support my 'hood but the wife and i can't eat that stuff. i need to go back and try the dry aged meat not that i need a reason to go back. nice people working behind the counter. the ferry building is a great place to blow some time.
author: roger b.

description: I love the big meat sandwich -- a big pile of pork barbeque on a roll.  I strayed recently and tried the buffalo wrap, and won't be trying it again.  So the review is for the BBQ sandwich (beef is also good).
author: Jay F.

description: meat loaf! meat loaf! meat loaft!!!! for $6!!!!  the perfect lunch or the perfect dinner with veggie on the side!!  the meat loaf is flavor-packed!!!  with a lil cheese in the middle!! omg... for $6 only????????   it's a steal!
author: Gigi T.

description: freshly sliced genoa salami in whatever quantity you want.  fabulous.
author: spiff e.

description: i had a skirt steak sandwich.  the steak was a bit sub par; but the bread and onion/mushroom/dressing are great.  i didn't have high expectation; but i was pleasantly surprised.  it's not the best sandwich; but acceptable.  i don't know about their pastrami sandwich, which might be much better.  for the one that i had, it's not the best/worst.
author: Gut O.

description: Great family business, fantastic products, even better prices, and the best service in town! They'll even get special order stuff for me - assorted bones, offal, and animals. This is my favorite store in all of SF.
author: Look and C.

description: this review is more for their lunch dishes than the actual store itself.  the sandwiches here are pretty decent but what excels is their hot pastrami sandwich.  haven't eaten it one in a while but will now do so since the memory has been reintroduced!
author: Swarup B.

description: i can't believe in all these reviews no one has mentioned GGMC's breakfast sandwiches.  they are unbelievable.  egg, cheese and bacon on a bun. i have to stop myself from getting one every day. seriously. $5, available before 11am.
author: rachel l.

description: yummy macaroni and cheese as well as chicken pot pie.  i've only come here for lunch but it was delicious.
author: Caroline P.

description: pretty darn good sam-wiches.. I had the pulled chicken and mustard... kinda messy so get some extra napkins. tip: eat it like a burrito :) ... gonna have to try the pastrami, next time... sat by the seating area by butcher and was absolutely entranced by all the MEATS!!!... next time, I'm bringing my mini cooler too.. hahahaha...eenie..meenie..miney..mo...
author: Roony P.

description: Everything here is fresh and delicious.  The best part of the whole place is the pulled pork sandwich with potato salad on the side.  Even the bread is delightful.  It's pillowy and toasted just right!
author: courtney c.

description: great meat, great service, get what you pay for! hubby volunteers to deal with the ferry building madness so i only get the benefits!
author: mm c.

description:
best. best. best!
probably the only place in the city that knows how to properly slice prosciutto... razor thin, wrapped in paper, no plastic. the guys are always friendly and quick for suggestions. whenever i return they always inquire as to how such and such dish turned out. respect your meat! buy it here!
author: Whitney F.

description: This place would be great if the people making the sandwiches would wash their hands. Today I ordered two sandwiches at the front counter, and the woman literally turned around, turned on the tap, ran her hands under the water like it would kill her, then turned off the water and dried her hands. Her hands were under the water for less than a second. Literally. No soap, nothing. This place already gives you your sandwich orders in thick plastic bags. Here's a thought: use plastic gloves to make the sandwiches!
author: Arthur B.
